{163}------------------------------------------------ # Waste management CIE Automotive deploys a recycling system that enables the internal recovery of thousands of tonnes of remains deriving from its various productive processes. The waste generated that cannot be recycled is collected by expert handlers which prioritise recycling over the landfill disposal method. In 2023\*, 1.69% was sent to landfills 87.35% was reused and the remaining 10.96% was directed to other forms of disposal. ### **Aluminium** The injection moulding and machining processes generate sizeable amounts of remains such as sprue, risers, starting pieces, etc. from the injection moulding process and shavings from the machining process. In both instances, the company reuses these remnants in the casting process. #### **Plastic** The plastics division recycles sprue and other remains returned by its injection moulding process. #### **Steel** This is the material with the highest associated volume of waste. As it cannot be recycled in full within the group's factories, it is delivered to a number of different local suppliers for full reuse. Image /page/163/Picture/10 description: The image shows a gray recycling bin with a white recycling symbol on it. The recycling symbol is made up of three arrows that form a triangle. Responsibility for waste generation does not end when that waste is removed from CIE Automotive's facilities. In addition to its waste minimisation plans, the company has devised a new waste classification system sorted by method of elimination, thereby seeking to reduce its environmental impact. ### **Food waste** Regardless of the fact that, due to the group's main activity as a manufacturer of automotive parts and components, this is not a material issue, CIE Automotive carries out different measures to avoid food waste. For example, the start-up of some biogas generation facilities from the food waste generated. *[For further information on waste generation by region, refer to the detailed table provided in the "Data tables and glossary" appendix]* #### **WASTE MANAGEMENT** *(\*) Includes emissions from discontinued German forging companies until June 30, 2023.* | MT | 2021 | 2022 | 2023* | |------------------------------------|-----------|-----------|-----------| | Hazardous waste

To the right of the words is a large number "23" with a quotation mark above the number. {164}------------------------------------------------ **5.6** # **Contribution to the decarbonisation of transport** **CIE Automotive's business is making a decisive contribution to the decarbonisation of road transport insofar as its parts are being incorporated into zeroemission vehicles. As a result, CIE Automotive's business qualifies as eligible for EU Taxonomy purposes as it is a priority for the region's the climate mitigation and climate change adaptation objectives.** Image /page/164/Picture/14 description: The image shows the CIE Automotive logo. The letter C is made up of two curved shapes, one above the other, that do not quite meet in the middle. The text "CIE Automotive" is in a simple, sans-serif font. On the right side of the image is the number 23. {165}------------------------------------------------ The EU Taxonomy is a classification system establishing the conditions that an economic activity has to meet in order to qualify as environmentally sustainable; specifically an activity must make a substantial contribution to one or more of the six environmental objectives established by the European Union, without having a significant detrimental impact (the Do No Significant Harm principle) on the other five, while meeting certain minimum social safeguards, defined as ILO Core Labour Conventions, the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. The ultimate goal of the Taxonomy is to redirect investment flows towards climate neutrality (net zero GHG emissions) via a two-pronged plan: helping players in the financial sector to decarbonise their securities and credit portfolios and giving non-financial companies (such as CIE Automotive) increased access to financing for technology, products and services in line with the guidelines set in the green transition framework. Following an analysis of its activities, CIE Automotive concluded that its productive processes, despite applying a range of methodologies, are encompassed by economic activity code NACE C29.3.2. Manufacture of other parts and accessories for motor vehicles. That economic activity is identified in Commission Delegated Regulation 2023/2485 of 27 June 2023, within the climate change mitigation objective, under code **3.18. Manufacture of automotive and mobility components**, which is defined as follows: *Manufacture, repair, maintenance, retrofitting, repurposing and upgrade of mobility components for zeroemission personal mobility devices and of automotive and mobility systems, components, separate technical units, parts and spare parts as defined in Article 3, points (18) to (21) and (23) of Regulation (EU) 2018/858 of the European Parliament and of the Council, type approved, designed, and constructed for use only in vehicles and buses of category M1, M2, M3, N1, N2 and N3, and in Article 3, points (15) to (18) and (21) in Regulation (EU) 168/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council, type approved, designed, and constructed for use only in vehicles of category L meeting the criteria set out in this Section and which are essential for delivering and improving the environmental performance of the vehicle.* As a result, as defined in the Regulation, CIE Automotive's economic activity is Taxonomyeligible in 2023. Given that this activity is being reported for the first time this year, as prescribed in Article 5 of Commission Delegated Regulation 2023/2485 of 27 June 2023, this year the Group only has to report eligibility; the alignment disclosures will be mandatory next year. In addition, in order to comply with the Regulation's requirements, the Group assessed the materiality of the three KPIs - turnover, CapEx and OPEX - in relation to the rest of the activities described in the Regulations, as outlined next. #### **TURNOVER** The key performance indicator (KPI) related to turnover is calculated as the percentage of turnover derived from Taxonomy-aligned activities (numerator) over total company turnover (denominator). Turnover is defined as the revenue recognised pursuant to International Accounting Standard (IAS) 1, paragraph 82(a), as adopted by Commission Regulation (EC) No 1126/2008. CIE Automotive, S.A. reports an eligible turnover KPI associated with activity 3.18 equivalent to 13.4% (turnover of 531,588 thousand euros). This percentage is arrived at by assigning each automotive part made by each of our factories to each of the original equipment makers that exist in the world. To obtain the percentage of electric vehicles made by all the platforms, CIE Automotive relied on information reported by IHS Markit, one of the largest data and analytics providers for many industries, with a solid presence in the automotive sector. IHS Markit provides the percentages of pure electric vehicles manufactured globally by each platform. CIE Automotive uses those percentages and the sales figures by platform as the basis for estimating turnover associated with zeroemissions vehicles. ### **COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATION (EU) 2020/852 ON CLIMATE TAXONOMY** Chairman and CEO's [statement](#page-2-0) **2023 [highlights](#page-5-0) 1** **Ready [for change](#page-15-0) 2** **Record [earnings](#page-53-0) Common responsibility, [shared benefits](#page-64-0) 3 4** #### **Our response to [the environmental](#page-141-0) challenge 5** About [this report](#page-229-0) **Responsible [management](#page-183-0) 6** [Data tables](#page-261-0) Image /page/165/Picture/20 description: The image shows the logo for CIE Automotive. To the right of the words is a large gray quotation mark and the number 23 in black. {166}------------------------------------------------ #### **CapEx** The CapEx KPI is measured as the percentage of fixed assets invested in eligible economic activities (numerator) over total assets acquired in the course of 2023 (denominator). That denominator (Total CapEx) is defined as additions to tangible and intangible assets during the financial year considered before depreciation, amortisation and any remeasurements, including those resulting from revaluations and impairments, for the relevant financial year and excluding fair value changes. It also includes additions resulting from business combinations. Accordingly, Total CapEx covers the costs recognised in keeping with IAS 16, IAS 38, IAS 40, IAS 41 and IFRS 16. In 2023, the CIE Automotive Group's CapEx totalled 311,884 thousand euros. With respect to activity 3.18. Manufacture of automotive and mobility components, the Group attempted to estimate how much of its CapEx is associated with that activity. That was not possible, however, since the physical assets used to make a part for use in an electric vehicle (eligible activity) are for the most part the same assets as are used to make parts for use in a non-electric vehicle (non-eligible activity). The company is working to develop and improve its methodology and technological toolkit to enable it to directly identify the CapEx associated directly with the eligible activity. As for the rest of its CapEx, the Group assessed whether the activities described in the Regulations are activities carried out by CIE Automotive, concluding that the amount of associated CapEx is not material. Likewise, in an attempt to comply with the Regulation requirements, the Tables include the most significant activities, even though the KPI reported by the company is equivalent to 0%, specifically, activities 7.3 Installation, maintenance and repair of energy efficiency equipment and 7.6 Installation, maintenance and repair of renewable energy technologies, which account for just 323 thousand euros, just 0.1% of the company's Total CapEx. It was concluded, therefore, that eligible CapEx under the Taxonomy is equivalent to 0%, so that alignment was not assessed for these activities; nevertheless, the eligible figures are provided in the section titled "Data tables and glossary". ### **OpEx** The OpEx KPI is defined as the percentage of Taxonomy-eligible OpEx (numerator) over total qualifying OpEx (denominator). That denominator covers direct noncapitalised costs that relate to research and development, building renovation measures, short-term lease, maintenance and repair, and any other direct expenditures relating to the day-to-day servicing of assets of property, plant and equipment by the undertaking or third party to whom activities are outsourced that are necessary to ensure the continued and effective functioning of such assets. In 2023, the CIE Automotive Group's qualifying OpEx amounted to 60,045 thousand euros, equivalent to 1.7% of the CIE Automotive Group's total OpEx in 2023 (3,567 million euros), so that the Group's qualifying OpEx is considered non-material and, as prescribed in section 1.1.3.2 of Annex I of the Commission Delegated Regulation of 6 July 2021, the numerator is therefore disclosed as being equal to zero, although the denominator is disclosed. | | Chairman

To the right of the words is a large number "23" with a gray quotation mark above the number. {167}------------------------------------------------ **5.7** # **Environmental risk management** The risk of accidents is covered by the company's civil liability insurance, while the company underwrites gradual pollution risk for the following factories in Spain: CIE Alcasting (aluminium), CIE Amaya (machining), CIE Galfor (forging), CIE Inyectametal (aluminium) and CIE Vilanova (aluminium). The last three facilities have integrated pollution prevention control (IPPC) permits. The claims limit on that gradual pollution insurance policy for those five factories is €3 million. To reinforce the management of its environmental and safety risks, CIE Automotive is working on a joint project with the technical department at its insurance broker, which is part of a bigger project addressed in the "Customer satisfaction" section. Specifically, a series of risks are being evaluated and prioritised in accordance with criteria established by the broker's risk engineers with the idea of formulating plans for their elimination, or at least mitigation. In 2023, this project focused on factories in North America, Brazil and India, prioritising the largest facilities or those with most assets involved. There were also follow-up visits to factories already inspected in prior years. Climate change also poses a threat to the company's ability to attain its strategic targets. To that end, CIE Automotive includes climate change risk in its risk mapping process, addressing not only the risks deriving from the company's impact on the environment and climate change, but also the risks posed to the company by the environment and climate change, and the interrelationship between the two. There is a dashed line through the middle of the number "2". {3}------------------------------------------------ Despite this uncertain climate, with its highlights and lowlights, in 2023 we once again marked new records in revenue, profitability and cash generation. We posted a net profit of €320.2 million, growth of 6.7% from 2022. Our bottom line was driven by topline growth of 3.1% to €3.96 billion and a stronger performance across all our markets, lifting the group's EBITDA to €713.2 million, implying a margin of 18.0%. We converted €447.4 million of that EBITDA into cash flow and brought our net debt down to €1.13 billion. In parallel, we paid our shareholders over €100 million, so delivering our commitment to paying out one-third of our net profit in dividends. As you can see, these are truly extraordinary numbers, especially considering the environment, which is why we want to thank and congratulate the entire CIE Automotive team for making them possible. We are optimistic about the future. We are ready to take advantage of the opportunities thrown up by the current market trends to surmount the challenges looming and continue to generate value for our shareholders, both through dividend payments and share price gains, as we have been doing for over 25 years. To do that, we have a unique business model, which has proven its worth in very tough times, articulated around six pillars: multiple locations, customer diversification, a multi-technology approach, disciplined investing, decentralised management and embedded sustainability standards. A model that will allow us to meet the ambitious targets set down in our 2025 Strategic Plan, which position us among the three most profitable automotive parts makers. With that in mind, in 2023 we redirected our financial and managerial resources to the businesses and markets offering most growth potential and highest returns. We acquired Iber-Oleff Brasil in a transaction that has reinforced our position in a growth market and allowed us to diversify our local customer base, and we sold our German forging factories specialised in the European truck market. Financial returns are not, however, our only ambition. Throughout last year we met all our compliance requirements and continued to engage all our professionals in the task of embedding ESG matters into our day-to-day operations. As signatories of the United Nations Global Compact, we aspire to contribute to delivery of the Sustainable Development Goals contemplated in the Agenda 2030 to end poverty, protect the planet and ensure that everyone can live in peace and prosperity. We are well aware that with 10 R&D centers and 108 plants in 17 countries, we are in a privileged position to do that. It is thanks to their dedication that we were able to continue to grow in 2023, generate wealth and mobilise other people so that they too become agents of change. In exchange, we provided them with €35 million worth of support measures (health insurance, food, transportation, etc.) and offered them as safe, stimulating and fair a place to work as possible, regardless of where they carry out their work. We lifted the percentage of women in our workforce by two points and by year-end had completed diversity and inclusion assessments at 93% of our factories, generating action plans for including people of different cultures, genders, generations and abilities. This is a particularly important milestone in countries whose populations are not sensitive to these matters and where there is no legislation around them. Our responsible doings have a domino effect on our supply chain. In 2023, we renewed our ISO 20400 Sustainable Procurement certification and rolled out Supply Chain Race 2 Zero, our project for rallying our worldwide suppliers around our goal of being net zero by no later than 2050, offering them resources, guidance and environmental training. This initiative is part of our new environmental roadmap which echoes and expands on the targets set in our 2025 Strategic Plan and establishes new steps towards climate neutrality. Last year we accompanied our customers with their efforts to decarbonise transport by investing in technology projects aimed at reducing the weight of our parts and improving material circularity. We also participated in a number of research programmes related with the electrification of transport, including Basquevolt, the Basque alliance for the creation of solid-state lithium batteries. All these activities favour progress in society and development in our business communities, which we supported in 2023 by contributing €497 million of tax and participating in community projects that benefitted over 41,500 people, projects we are certain will have a multiplier effect in the long term. In 2023 we demonstrated that the future is not preordained, that it is our actions that mark the difference. We know that much remains to be done to create the fair, prosperous and sustainable world we all long for but we are convinced that we are taking steps in the right direction and that is something we are proud of. Inauguration of the company's first greenfield factory in Mexico, in the town of Celaya. #### **2006** Entry into the Chinese market, CIE Automotive's first Asian stop, with a greenfield project, CIE Automotive Parts Shanghai. Creation of the CIE Desc joint venture in Mexico, marking a qualitative leap in the ability to service North American customers. #### **2009** Entry into the roof systems segment with the acquisition of Advanced Comfort Systems (ACS). #### **2011** Reverse merger with Dominion via Inssec. CIE Autometal listed on the Sao Paulo stock exchange. ### **2012** Initial foray into the US market with the acquisition of Century Plastics. Maiden forging factory in Asia with the creation of the Nanjing Automotive Forging joint venture (NFJ). #### **2013** Entry into the Indian market via the strategic alliance with India's Mahindra & Mahindra Group, giving rise to MCIE (since renamed, CIE India), a listed company. ### **2014** Delisting of CIE Automotive's Brazilian subsidiary, Autometal. #### **2015** Endorsement of the United Nations Global Compact, approval of the group's CSR & Sustainability Policy and creation of the Cross-Group CSR Committee (currently, the Cross-Group ESG Committee). #### **2016** CIE Automotive lists its technology subsidiary, Dominion. #### **2017** Publication of the Global Supply Chain Manual. Celebration of the first CSR Day (currently called ESG Days). #### **2018** CIE Automotive's shares in Dominion distributed to the company's shareholders in the form of an extraordinary dividend. Creation of the Suppliers Portal as a management tool focused on overseeing ESG risks. #### **2019** Acquisition of Inteva's roof systems division, positioning CIE Automotive in the global top 3 in the design and manufacture of roofs. #### **2020** CIE Automotive ties its €690 million syndicated loan to green finance criteria. Membership of the SERNAUTO Responsible Business Committee. First share buyback and cancellation programme. #### **2021** CIE Automotive turns 25 and unveils its 2025 Strategic Plan. #### **2022** Commitment to achieve climate neutrality before 2050 announced. Second share buyback and cancellation programme. This permanent scrutiny allows it to mitigate the key market risks and leverage its competitive advantages.** Next is a description of the main challenges and opportunities, with further information provided in "Risk management - Market risks": ### **Economic slowdown** According to the International Monetary Fund's estimates, the global economy grew at a moderate rate of 3% in 2023 and will slow to 2.9% in 2024, well below the 3.5% recorded in 2022 and average growth of 3.8% between 2000 and 2019. Prospects are, however, very difference between the advanced economies, where the slowdown is expected to be more pronounced, and emerging and developing economies, which are expected to register higher growth. Image /page/19/Picture/10 description: The image shows a black and white icon of an electric car with a euro symbol above it. The car has a charging cable plugged into its side. The euro symbol is a circle with a horizontal line through the center. #### **Heavy investment in electric vehicles** The transition to electric mobility is requiring heavy investments in new technology around batteries, vehicle autonomy and electric propulsion systems. The OEMs need to design specific vehicle platforms, requiring significant investment in engineering and design. Automotive suppliers need to improve their production lines to adapt them for electric vehicles which implies, in addition to capital expenditure, investing in skills. Image /page/19/Picture/30 description: The image shows a black circle with a white Euro symbol inside it. Above the circle is a black arrow pointing upwards. The background is a light peach color. ### **Increase in borrowing costs** The automotive sector players were faced by an increase in borrowing costs as a result of the successive interest rate increases implemented to curb inflation. The increase in the cost of money left many OEMs and suppliers, which had leveraged up to deal with the fallout from the pandemic and/or invest in vehicle electrification, in a precarious position. Image /page/19/Picture/15 description: The image shows a black and white icon of an electric car being charged. The car is depicted in silhouette with a charging cable plugged into its side. Above the car are two euro symbols with a lightning bolt in between them, suggesting the cost of electricity. The overall design is simple and graphic, likely intended for use as a symbol or sign related to electric vehicles and charging costs. . #### **Price war in electric vehicle segment** Growth in electric vehicles is driving the OEMs to cut prices aggressively in order build a position in the market. A price war broke out in January when one of the electric vehicle segment leaders cut the price of its cheaper models in a move that was quickly followed by the other OEMs, worried they would be left out of this niche; discounts went as high as 15% on some models in China. In fact, the Chinese electric vehicle makers are making major inroads, exporting very cheap models to Europe. ### **CHALLENGES** Despite the sector's strong performance in 2023 in the wake of global supply chain normalisation, the business faced certain challenges that could well become more pressing in the years to come: Image /page/19/Picture/7 description: The image shows a black and white icon of a euro symbol inside a circle. To the right of the words is a large number "23" with a gray quotation mark above it. {22}------------------------------------------------ Market performance by region #### **Europe:** Production in Europe totalled 17.3 million vehicles in 2023, annual growth of 12.6%, reflecting the gradual supply chain normalisation. In 2023, purchases were boosted by the need to renew an aged vehicle fleet (especially rental car fleets) and electric and plug-in purchase incentives. In the electric segment the European OEMs are facing a surge in Chinese electric vehicle imports. The resulting price war is putting the weaker parts suppliers in a tough situation, negotiating prices that leave their EBIT margins at under 5%. Faced by this situation, while Brussels has officially started an anti-subsidy investigation on electric cars from China, the various national governments are rolling out initiatives to protect their industries. For this and other strategic reasons, the Chinese OEMs are looking into options for setting up manufacturing in Europe down the line. For example, in December BYD formally announced plans to build a factory in Hungary in phases. The Europe coming year losing share The European market is forecast to remain flat in the coming years, as is expected of a mature market that is losing share to other areas of the world. ### **North America:** Vehicle production in North America totalled 15.7 million units, up 9.7% from 2022. This growth, considered high for a mature market, is attributable to the positive impact of the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), which provides electric vehicle buyers a tax credit of up to \$7,500 if the car meets certain regional production requirements. A flat evolution is expected in the coming years, typical of an already mature market that is losing weight in favor of other markets. One negative development was the simultaneous strike at three OEMs - General Motors, Stellantis and Ford - in the US and Canada. Production foregone during the stoppages is estimated at 203,793 vehicles. Unlike Europe and despite the market's maturity, vehicle production in the US is expected to increase by 1% in 2024, in large part, but not entirely, due to the recovery in volumes in the wake of the strike. Medium term, the market is expected to revisit its pre-pandemic levels by 2026, again setting it apart from the European market. ### *Vehicle purchase incentives* In August 2022, the US passed the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), which includes \$369bn in clean energy investments as well as provisions that will lower the cost of prescription drugs and increase taxes on large corporations. Of particular interest for the automotive sector is the vehicle purchase incentive and the infrastructure tax credit. Overall, the bill is projected to help cut greenhouse gas emissions by about 40% from 2005 levels by the end of the decade. The Inflation Reduction Act contains financial incentives to encourage the purchase of electric and hydrogen fuel cell powered vehicles as well as the deployment of charging stations. Provisions in the IRA provide a tax credit for the purchase of the vehicle itself and a tax credit for the purchase and installation of charging assets or charging infrastructure. Tax breaks mitigated the pronounced rise in interest rates in 2023. The big announcement last year was BYD's acquisition of the old Ford factory in Bahía, which is now expected to produce two electric cars and one hybrid model, as well as electric trucks and buses. Production is expected to start in the second half of 2024 with initial annual capacity of 150,000 units, a figure expected to double to 300,000 from 2025. Growth in production is expected to accelerate in 2024, to 3% and, most notably in 2025 and 2026, when production growth is forecast at 6% and 7%, respectively. Some of the anticipated growth is attributable to the fact that the Brazilian central bank has already started to cut interest rates. #### **India:** Demand for vehicles in India broke new records in 2023. Production increased by 4.4% to 5.4 million units, despite strong levels already in 2022. As well as a strong performance in the passenger vehicle segment, other segments with even greater growth potential started to recover: commercial vehicles (+0%); motorcycles (+4%) and tractors (-2%). Notably electrification also started to make inroads in this market: in early October, Tata announced it would launch eight electric models in 2030. This growth is expected to get a further injection from public initiatives designed to draw investments related with electric vehicles. In 2023, electric car sales volumes increased by around 90% (88% as of November). However, combustion-engine vehicles are expected to continue to dominate this market. As for the outlook for light vehicle production, growth is expected to take a breather in 2024, consolidating the sharp growth recorded last year before going on to regain traction, with growth of 4/5% forecast for both 2025 and 2026. ### **China:** The world's largest vehicle maker increased production by 10.0% in 2023. Although domestic demand appears to be slowing, Chinese production was boosted by the extension of tax relief for electric vehicles until 2027. Moreover, the Chinese OEMs are growing in foreign markets thanks to a price-based growth strategy. Annual growth to 2026 is forecast at 3%. Climate change regulations are tackling two key fronts. Firstly, they are requiring the use of greener energy sources, focused primarily on electrification. Secondly, all sector players must mitigate their carbon footprints taking a lifecycle approach. ### **Demographic trends** There are many opposing demographic trends unfolding simultaneously around the world whose ultimate overall effect on the automotive sector is expected to be clearly positive. - More than half of forecast population growth is concentrated in Africa, but the most of the world's population is located in Asia (60%), with Europe losing share (10%.) - Life expectancies are rising and birth rates dropping, driving population ageing. - Urbanisation is a parallel trend and we are also seeing - mainly regional - migratory displacements of populations. #### **Technological change** The world is moving towards a Fourth Industrial Revolution, which will change our lives and make productive processes, including those of the automotive sector, more efficient. The emerging improved and more efficient vehicle architectures are based on the use of the right materials and their correct application, which means that different technologies will have a role to play in the next-generation, multi-material vehicles. ### **Macroeconomics and geopolitics** - Emerging market opportunities: the Chinese, Indian and Brazilian economies, to name a few, are expected to experience sharp growth in the coming years. - National protectionism: initially perceived as a threat, protectionism strategies are no longer expected to have a significant impact on the automotive sector. Nowadays they are looking for aspects related with comfort, such as spaciousness, driver assistance and smart infrastructure, to the detriment of other attributes such as power, aerodynamics and external aesthetics. Within the comfort thrust, the penetration of roof systems is outpacing the general automotive market. ### **Safety and protection** Vehicle safety prioritisation is making manufacturing more complex and increasing the number of parts and their added value. Today's cars are being fitted with sophisticated driver assistance systems that prevent accidents and other passive safety systems designed to mitigate damage and injuries in the event of a collision; those systems are being embedded in the chassis and bodywork, for example, as well as shaping seatbelt and airbag development. Growing safety and protection requirements for passengers and other road users is requiring the introduction of more complex solutions involving different materials, reinforcing the astuteness of the multitechnology approach. #### **Autonomous and connected car** Major progress has been made on autonomous driving in recent years, thanks to which important driver assistance features have been introduced to new cars. However, the mainstreaming of the autonomous car in the coming years continues to face obstacles. In parallel, users are demanding greater connectivity between their cars and the outside world (virtual assistants, automation, etc.), all of which requires establishing high-speed connections. This approach allows it to respond to its customers' demands and the growing body of legislation around sustainability, while also locking in profitable, long-term growth by driving efficiency and innovation so as to minimise its negative impacts.** ### **Global Compact** CIE Automotive's public commitment to sustainable development dates back to 2015, when it signed its endorsement of the United Nations Global Compact. That endorsement implied the public assumption of responsibility in key areas including human and labour rights, environmental protection and anti-corruption. Eight years later, as a Signatory of the Spanish Chapter of the Global Compact, the group has moved beyond its respect for the Company's 10 universally recognised principles and become an agent of systematic change in the shift towards a sustainable economy. This policy defines the fundamental principles and general framework for building sustainability practices into the company's business model and strategy. Effective application of these principles and the potential risks associated with it are addressed in CIE Automotive's Risk Management and Control Policy. ### **Management monitoring** Supervision of ESG and sustainability management falls to the Board of Director's ESG Committee, which delegates oversight of application of the principles in the Cross-Group ESG Committee. This monitoring process takes the form of 79 ESG indicators that measure performance in different areas. The KPIs are in turn included in each factory's management plans and are used to track delivery of the sustainability aspects of the 2025 Strategic Plan. The group's social responsibility extends to its supply chain. Indeed, CIE Automotive was the first company in its sector to create a supplier platform devoted solely to managing and evaluating ESG matters. It sets ambitious and quantifiable business and ESG targets and details the specific lines of work for achieving them. The two blocks are interdependent and necessary to attain sustainable profitability.** ### **BUSINESS STRATEGY** CIE Automotive's business strategy is articulated around the generation of operating cash flow and so translates into significant deleveraging over its time horizon, enabling it to invest up to €1.5 billion without its leverage (net debt-to-EBITDA) rising above 2x. The momentum in operating cash flow is being driven by margin expansion, which more than offset the rise in interest rates in 2023. The amount set aside for investments may be used for any type of transaction that maximises the company's returns, including M&A deals, share buybacks, the purchase of minority interests, etc. The criteria will always be to prioritise transactions that maximise value generation at a given point in time. #### **ORGANIC\* COMMITMENTS EMBEDDED IN THE 2025 STRATEGIC PLAN** Image /page/41/Picture/11 description: The image shows a black and white icon representing financial growth in euros. There is a gray quotation mark to the left of the number 23. {42}------------------------------------------------ #### **BUSINESS LINES OF INITIATIVE** In order to deliver its commitments, CIE Automotive has defined four lines of initiative around the key automotive sector trends (refer to "Sector background"): electrification, Industry 4.0, comfort and international expansion. These lines of initiative likewise respond to the market changes identified as a risk factor, as detailed in the "Risk management" chapter. **Electrification** The company wants to take advantage of the opportunity afforded by decarbonisation of the transport sector to create new value-added products for electric vehicles, particularly in EV motors, power electronics, gearboxes and batteries. At present, 80% of the products made by CIE Automotive are compatible with both electrified and combustionpowered vehicles. #### **Industry 4.0** Immersed in the fourth industrial revolution, CIE Automotive is gradually adopting smart manufacturing tools and different enabling technologies. These tools interact with and learn from each other and feature sensorisation capabilities that make it possible to capture data which is later analysed using algorithms. Implementation of these technologies is not only making our processes more efficient but is also reducing our environmental impact by cutting prototype volumes, energy and raw material consumption, product rejects and scrap generation. #### **International expansion** The company seeks geographical diversification by investing in countries where vehicle penetration is low and growth expectations are high. Broadly speaking, until 2025, the plan is for all the divisions to add capacity and develop new products that add more value and address their existing customers' emerging needs. In parallel, the sales teams are working intensely to bring in new customers. #### **Comfort** CIE Automotive's strategy in the comfort area is concentrated at its roof systems division. More specifically, it is looking to consolidate its position in bottomloaded roofs and fixed glass roofs with shades. It also wants to be able to incorporate panoramic roofs into both fixed and movable sunroofs, addressing all ranges. The company is also focusing on thinner roofs equipped with flat roller blind technology, which are particularly necessary in the electric vehicle segment. Lastly, it is working on ambient comfort by adding spot lighting to both its roofs and their shades. Image /page/42/Picture/20 description: The image shows the logo for CIE Automotive. To specify and evaluate progress towards those qualitative goals, CIE Automotive is tracking 79 specific KPIs with defined targets and timelines. These indicators are part of the management plans at all of the company's factories, which report to the corporate areas quarterly, half-yearly or annually, depending on the stipulated frequency. All of that information gets consolidated into a global ESG dashboard hosted within the group's corporate intranet. Progress on the various indicators is reported to the Board's ESG Committee and the CEO, who has tasked the Cross-Group ESG Committee with overseeing delivery of various KPIs. The KPIs are reviewed periodically and realigned with the most updated context assessment, which factors in the latest trends in the automotive industry, stakeholder demands and regulatory developments, among other aspects The targets and the work being done by the corporate areas driving their attainment are articulated around four strategic lines of initiative: CIE culture, ethical commitment, eco-efficiency and active listening. In parallel, the company is working on projects in the electric motor, battery and power electronics systems in order to continue to penetrate the electrified vehicle segment and so contribute to the decarbonisation of transportation in the use phase. CIE Automotive collaborates with a range of research programmes targeting decarbonisation at both the regional and international levels. Those programmes are looking at systems for zero-emission vehicles, whether battery-powered or fuel-cell electric vehicles. In batteries, CIE Automotive is also participating in the Basque initiative for the production of solid-state batteries, which is planning to build 10 GWh of capacity. Basquevolt plans to commission a production line in four years' time, entailing €700 million of investment and generating more than 800 direct jobs. Solid-state batteries will deliver a substantial increase in battery autonomy, while lowering their costs and reducing dependence on certain critical materials. That will also lead to democratisation of the electric vehicle, paving the way for costs of €15,000 per vehicle, making them accessible to most citizens. This project considers the life cycle of the new batteries, including disassembly, recycling or reuse. Image /page/49/Picture/11 description: The image shows the logo for CIE Automotive. Here the engineering area is working on a number of different projects: - Introduction of new product functions, so reducing the number of parts. In the roof systems division, this means including lighting, display screens and photovoltaic cells in the systems. - Launch of eco-design tools for incorporation into new product and project processes. In 2023 this project emphasised the incorporation of disassembly and recycling criteria at the product design phase. - Projects to increase the circularity of polymer transformation technologies. - Introduction of recycled materials into roofing textiles that can help cut product emissions up to three-fold. - Innovation in technologies that reduce the use of fuel and chemical products, such as ESG+ technology, in roofs and side windows, delivering a consideration reduction in waste generation and the products' environmental footprints. - Continuation of the multi-year projects aimed at rationalising the use of raw materials, which are being rolled out across all technologies and regions, developing new process concepts with the potential to directly reduce our scope 3 emissions. #### **Vehicle light-weighting** Helping make vehicles lighter is a key thrust of CIE Automotive's innovation strategy due to its contribution to reducing the use of raw materials, lowering fuel consumption in an internal combustion vehicle while in use or increasing the autonomy of an electric vehicle: - Aluminium forging for chassis and suspension parts, achieving very compelling mechanical property ratios relative to weight - Technology shift marked by increased use of polymer materials, reducing the bill of materials by adding functions - Development of the new thin roof concept which weighs less and takes up less space - Reducing roof weights by using resin transfer moulding (RTM) frames ## **Helping make vehicles lighter is a key thrust** of CIE Automotive's innovation strategy Image /page/50/Picture/26 description: The image shows the logo for CIE Automotive. To the right of the words is a large number "23". {51}------------------------------------------------ CIE Automotive is future-proofing its factories by adopting new tools and technologies. The number of data control and capture sensors embedded in its equipment and production is growing all the time. In parallel, collaborative robots (cobots) are popping up on its production lines, providing employees with real-time information over new interfaces. In addition, data analytics is being used in a growing number of technologies, underpinned by increasingly efficient deep learning algorithms available in tools requiring lowcode programming. In 2023, the company finished the demo for a new intralogistics platform for the automation of the transportation of finished products with the goal of establishing a continuous loop for the delivery and collection of finished product packaging for storage up high in the warehouse. Current mobility trends point to improving the user experience shaped by a keen interest in comfort and connectivity. Against this backdrop, CIE Automotive is innovating intensely in its roof systems area, specifically: This solution adds flexibility, efficiency and traceability to the logistics processes by means of the smart management of different sensors and mobile devices, including automotive guided vehicles (AGVs) and autonomous mobile robots (AMRs). These devices are being integrated into the factories' existing management systems and other sensors to give users visibility and control in real time using 5G technology. The 5G standard is crucial on account of the massive volumes of data involved, the density of the devices, the broad coverage required in spaces like these and the immediacy needed for the entire intralogistics ecosystem to work optimally. In tandem the company has added cobots in assembly and inspection operations and when using chemical products. The use of these collaborative robots enables more precise product dosing and delivers a significant reduction in their environmental impact. Faced with higher borrowing costs on the back of successive interest rate increases, which put the weakest suppliers in serious jeopardy, the company locked in the liquidity and term structure needed by refinancing its debt and increasing the share of its borrowings at fixed rates to 54.5%. In parallel, it continued to honour its sustainability commitments by tying its borrowing costs to delivery of those pledges.** CIE Automotive's net debt came down by approximately €143.5 million in 2023 for an adjusted year-end balance of €1.13 billion, implying a net debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 1.56x. That leaves the company in a comfortable position for undertaking new strategic investments designed to further its profitable growth and reinforce its position in highgrowth markets. CIE Automotive set a new milestone in 2019 when it arranged its first sustainable financing facility. This moderate performance contrasts with stronger gains in the Stoxx Europe 600 Automobiles & Parts (+19%) and Ibex 35 (+23%), due, in part, to a more stringent base effect in the case of the company's shares. Over the past five years, CIE Automotive's share price has increased by 20%, significantly outperforming the Stoxx Europe 600 Automobiles & Parts (which gained 2% over that timeframe) and the Ibex 35 (just 1%). Comparing CIE Automotive's share price with the corrections sustained by most of the parts makers included in the broader sector index, the difference is even more striking. Over the course of 2023, however, there continued to be a lag between CIE Automotive's fundamentals and its share price performance. Specifically, its share price remained well below the consensus target price of €31.38 assigned by the universe of analysts that follow the company. In contrast to other automotive parts makers, the company has not had to issue any profit warnings in the face of the recent sector complexity, remaining among the top three sector players in terms of profitability and growth prospects. However, these achievements have not been priced in by the market. The automotive industry is not currently attractive to investors and mediumcap stocks are not managing to attract funds from the major investment funds, a combination that is not helping CIE Automotive. On top of this, liquidity fell in 2022, particularly after the company exited the Ibex 35 index. The company's share price performance over the last year should not cloud its performance over a longer time horizon. Under this programme, projects are being ranked by geography for close monitoring. Last year the company also organised internal communication seminars, shared best practices and developed new procedures for scaling up incidents with the goal of avoiding not only legal noncompliance but indeed any source of customer dissatisfaction. The company focused on the prevention of possible defects, an effort that included the reinforcement of procedures and controls, enhanced traceability of all products, analysis of the causes of potential defects and constant communication with its customers. Customer satisfaction is one of CIE's key success factors. To that end, the company has a satisfaction control system that measures, tracks and analyses customer feedback with the aim of proposing improvements at the various factories, where needed. This system is used to assess each factory's performance and to quantify customer perceptions on the basis of audits, assessments and current data. That information is then used to compile an annual report and draw up corrective action plans as necessary. ### **Consumer claims, complaints and grievance systems** Despite its best efforts on the product quality front, both preventive during the design and industrialisation phases and corrective during manufacturing, on occasion deviations lead to customer claims. When that happens, it is vital to react immediately to prevent the supply of nonconforming parts and conduct in-depth analysis of the root causes. The solutions provided are shared with and applied to all potentially affected facilities and technologies. The company did not receive any significant fines or penalties as a result of legal proceedings related with incidents of noncompliance with product information or labelling in 2023. The average earnings of the company's female employees amounted to 92.4% of what the men earn on average, compared to 94.9% in 2022. Specifically, female employees earned €17,510 on average, compared to the €18,960 earned by the men. It is important to note that the salaries were converted to euros at yearend exchange rates and include the salaries of all of the group's factories and offices, so that the indicator considers people from different regions, with different technical skills and from countries with markedly different levels of economic, social and labour market development. The increase in the gender pay gap in 2023 is primarily attributable to two factors: Image /page/93/Figure/29 description: This image is a bar chart comparing data from 2022 and 2023 for CIE Automotive in different regions and countries. The chart includes data for Europe, specifically Spain, Germany, Slovakia, Czech Republic, and Romania. It also includes data for Asia, specifically China and India, and North America, specifically the US and Mexico. Finally, it includes data for Brazil. The data for 2022 is as follows: Europe: 94.9%, Spain: 78%, Germany: 94%, Slovakia: 89%, Czech Republic: 77%, Romania: 80%, China: 88%, India: 77%, US: 78%, Mexico: 71%, and Brazil: 77%. The data for 2023 is as follows: Europe: 92.4%, Spain: 81%, Germany: 87%, Slovakia: 88%, Czech Republic: 75%, Romania: 85%, China: 89%, India: 79%, US: 76%, Mexico: 65%, and Brazil: 74%. - The first, which is not entirely within the group's control, is the situation at the factories newly acquired in Hungary and Brazil, where the pay gap before their acquisition was above the group average, so bringing the 2023 group average down. - The second relates to a development within the group, which is working hard to bring more women to work at its factories. Among these initiatives, the Ulysses Programme, which combines mobility and talent attraction, stands out. Thanks to this initiative, young professionals from different plants and of different nationalities attend an excellence training centre in the Basque region before going on to build their skills at the group's emblematic factories in Spain and Italy. This programme delivers four key objectives: embedding the group's values; facilitating cross-country communication going forward; fostering intragroup relationships; and providing the group with highly skilled professionals. Since resuming the programme in the wake of the pandemic, it has been expanded to the point of exceeding the Strategic Plan target. Currently, 17 students from four countries (Brazil, Czech Republic, India and Mexico) are participating in the newest edition of the Ulysses Programme, which began in October 2023, so topping the figures established in the 2025 Strategic Plan, which called for 15 participants from three different markets. Moreover, the retention rate, two years after completing the programme, currently stands at 90% for the first edition and 100% for the second edition, likewise delivering the related Strategic Plan retention rate target of at least 80%. #### **TARGET DELIVERY** The Ulysses Programme **combines mobility and talent attraction** #### **Phases of the programme** The Ulysses programme is structured into two distinct phases: #### **Phase 1:** Depending on the originating factory, the students participate in different technology modules (polymers, metal and metal injection). There are also two common modules addressing key soft skills and the company's lean management philosophy: Entrepreneurship & Innovation and Lean Manufacturing. #### **Phase 2:** The students spend several months at a factory. A large number of CIE Automotive's legacy plants are involved in this training initiative, including CIE Orbelan, CIE Inyectametal, CIE Udalbide, CIE Egaña and CIE Galfor, among others, as well as the corporate Engineering Department, the corporate Controller Department and the Laboratory located in AIC - Amorebieta. New this year was the incorporation of youths from Eastern Europe and the provision of training development of structural staff, unlike previous exercises that focused only on production plant personnel. This protocol addresses the prevention of mobbing and of sexual or gender harassment and includes several preventive measures, such as zero-tolerance towards harassment, shared employee responsibility for monitoring workplace conduct and the implementation of communication programmes. The full text of the protocol is available for consultation on the corporate website. In 2023, CIE Automotive received and managed 17 complaints related with matters addressed in the protocol, which is one more than in 2022. In the wake of these complaints, the group took significant disciplinary action, even laying off one of the employees involved. It is important to note that when CIE Automotive integrates new companies, as it did in Hungary (CIE Salgglas) and Brazil (Iberoleff- CIE Autometal Salto) last year, the factory managers and HR heads are asked to sign the group's Harassment Protocol and Human Rights Policy by way of endorsement. The documents comprising this framework or system include: - The reported OHS Policy and OHS Target documents. - The documented procedures required under benchmark applicable regulations. - The documents needed to ensure effective process planning, operation and control. - The legally applicable requirements and other standards adopted by the group. - The registers required under benchmark applicable regulations. CIE Automotive has 15 corporate procedures and 'formats' related with delivery of the targets set in the OHS area. Those specific procedures establish the occupational health and safety requirements to be upheld in all activities. The 'formats' compile relevant information about the controls, measures and, in general, data yielded by an activity or a methodology for carrying it out. #### **Model and structure** Each factory has its own health and safety plan, which is put together on the basis of a framework system that is subjected to continual audit as part of the group's workplace safety management systems. This structure enables the company to adapt safety measures for each factory and evaluate the measures taken by it on this front as a whole. Individual action plans are formulated every year to deliver the targeted level of improvement defined on the basis of the prior year's performance. Every facility has a health and safety officer who, in addition to monitoring accidents and safety indicators, is tasked with ergonomics, avoiding exposure to harmful substances and managing psychosocial risks, as well as coordinating health monitoring. The factories have an outside safety service that covers the four legally-stipulated areas of accident prevention expertise and a health and safety officer at each of its productive facilities. The corporate Health And Safety Department regularly audits the factories, maintains the corporate intranet and serves as contact point for issues related with occupational health and safety. Between 2017 and 2021, the US firefighter forces responded to an estimated annual average of 3,396 structure fires related with hot work, according to the most recent NFPA report. These fires caused average annual fatalities and civilian injuries of 19 and 120, respectively. The statistics regarding worker injuries and fatalities related with hot work paint an even darker picture. Faced with that reality, in 2023 CIE Automotive introduced a new procedure for controlling and regulating hot work at all group factories (CIE CO PR P 16) which is expected to become fully operational over the course of 2024. Under this procedure all internal or external work requiring the use of fire or combustion will be verified. ### **Fire safety self-inspections** Beyond the emergency measures in place across the factories, the group is planning to introduce a systematic method for performing regular fire safety inspections. Specifically, inspections will take place at least monthly at all group factories covered by the new hot work procedure - CIE CO PR P 16 - verifying their critical facilities and establishing action plans to address all deviations detected. CIE Automotive guarantees the health and safety of the workers of all companies entering its places of work. The so-called Business Activity Coordination unit is therefore one of the most important areas of the health and safety effort. The vast volumes of documents and large number of companies and workers involved mean that this unit needs to be digitalised to perform its coordination work more effectively. The resulting coordination software platform is intended to reduce workplace risks, ensure compliance with applicable regulations and increase cooperation between contracting and subcontractor firms, as well as reduce the costs associated with workplace accidents. The idea is to integrate internal and external health and safety management and, if correctly applied, guarantee compliance with applicable legal requirements. That threw up the challenge of involving its suppliers in the company's commitment to becoming climate neutral by 2050. So began the Supply Chain Race 2 Zero project. The first step in this race to decarbonisation was to understand its suppliers' real GHG emission figures, their level of commitment to reducing them and their advances to date. The idea was also to identify suppliers that need help tackling this challenge. The group surveyed its main suppliers in all its geographies regarding their engagement around decarbonisation. The suppliers were selected on the basis of their emissions impact and/or procurement volume. The goal of Supply Chain Race 2 Zero is to focus on helping in the weakest areas. In general, the smaller and more local suppliers need support in the form of resources, guidance or environmental knowledge. This partnership includes information about energy efficiency, technical solutions and identification of areas for improvement, among other forms of assistance. To the right of the words is a large number 23 with a quotation mark above the 2. {119}------------------------------------------------ # Renewal of ISO 20400 Sustainable procurement certification In 2023, CIE Automotive renewed its ISO 20400 Sustainable procurement certification, remaining the only company in Spain to boast this quality seal. Annual renewal took place following a rigorous audit by AAERCE, the Spanish association of procurement professionals, under the sustainable procurement requirements governed by IFPSM (International Federation of Purchasing and Supply Management). The audit confirmed that the company had met the requirements formulated the previous year. With this renewal, CIE Automotive ratified the operational excellence of its Procurement Department and the contribution being made by the latter to the company's broader sustainability and social responsibility policies. To achieve this certification, which is based on UNE-15896 Value added purchasing management, the following parameters were appraised: - Purchasing policy. - Selection and monitoring of suppliers. - Purchasing processes, ESG requirements in all group purchases. - Buyer training. - Risk management, purchase specifications and internal organisation. - Alignment with new regulations and requirements in the areas of due diligence, taxonomy and diversity and inclusion. Beyond the recognition that comes with the certification, it represents a challenge for the procurement teams as it not only requires compliance with ISO 20400 by the company but also with ESG standards by its suppliers. So, for example, the company cannot make an acquisition without a positive assessment of the target's management. In this way, ISO 20400 certification reinforces the company's sustainability policies by extending them to the entire supply chain and lays the groundwork for making further progress in ESG as it requires: - Ensuring supply chain security. - Avoiding financial, environmental and reputational risks. - Inspiring confidence among investors, consumers and other stakeholders. - Fostering employee wellbeing and contributing to opening new markets for products and services. - Being prepared to achieve the decarbonisation targets CIE Automotive has set for itself, its supply chain constituting its main source of emissions (Scope 3). ## **CIE Automotive is the only Spanish** automotive parts maker to boast **ISO 20400 certification** Chairman and CEO's [statement](#page-2-0) **2023 [highlights](#page-5-0) 1** | 2 | Ready for change | |---|------------------| |---|------------------| **Record [earnings](#page-53-0) 3** **Common responsibility, [shared benefits](#page-64-0) 4** | 5 | Our response to the environmental challenge | |---|---------------------------------------------| |---|---------------------------------------------| About [this report](#page-229-0) **Responsible [management](#page-183-0) 6** [Data tables](#page-261-0) Image /page/119/Picture/30 description: The image shows the CIE Automotive logo. The number "23" has a dashed line running through the middle of it. {122}------------------------------------------------ ## ESG Supplier Portal In the automotive components sector CIE Automotive set itself apart in 2018 when it created, in a sector first, a Suppliers Portal devoted exclusively to managing ESG aspects in the supply chain. Five years on, this Portal remains a crucial tool for implementing uniform ESG requirements regardless of the nationality of the company's suppliers or their place of business. The Portal is an online platform that is free to use and accessible from the Supply Chain tab on the corporate website. Existing and prospective suppliers of products and services to CIE Automotive can register. By year-end 2023, a total of 8,000 suppliers populated the company's supplier base. Any candidates that did not complete or pass the assessment received a message encouraging them to complete the process and/or improve their scores with the help of CIE Automotive. For the first time in 2023, non-productive, or indirect suppliers, with annual procurement volume of over €500,000 are now required to register with the Portal and submit to an ESG assessment, an obligation previously limited to suppliers of productive materials, or direct suppliers. #### A **productive or direct purchase** is the purchase of products or services that form part of the final products received by the group's customers. The raw materials used in any of its technologies, the parts included in its end products (rubber, textiles, fasteners) and even subcontracting processes (heat treatments, machining) therefore fall into this category. Exceptionally, the tooling used in productive processes is also included within productive purchasing. In short, productive purchases account for over 70% of the group's total procurement spend and are the biggest source of Scope 3 emissions for CIE Automotive. In contrast a **non-productive or indirect purchase** is one that facilitates the production process but is not an integral part of the end products delivered to its customers. #### *[Refer to the Procurement families]* ### **Enhanced management** In addition to facilitating assessment, the Suppliers Portal is a source of reference and valuable information for our procurement managers. Following its redesign in 2022, a new interface was developed in 2023 to visualise, manage and extract information related with the audits conducted by CIE Automotive on current or prospective suppliers. This new feature enhances the procurement teams' management efforts and adds exclusive ESG audits to the range of traditional audits. The company's traditional audits also include a pass/fail ESG section. New conditions were added in 2023, specifically: - - • Modern slavery: CIE Automotive wants to ensure that there is no place for modern slavery in its supply chain, in other words, that no person is forced to work in subhuman conditions they cannot refuse on account of coercion, threats or the abuse of power. • Use of private of public security forces: Suppliers may not hire or use private or public security forces to protect the company if, due to a lack of training or control by the supplier, their deployment could give rise to human rights violations. To that end it has included a specific section within the Ethics Framework section of its Global Supply Chain Manual urging its suppliers to participate in this process, introducing a due diligence report and five guidelines for correct compliance: establishing robust business management systems; identifying suppliers that supply mineral conflicts; designing a strategy for mitigating the risks detected; carrying out an external audit; and reporting on due diligence efforts in the group's annual reports. The due diligence response is currently in the process of being implemented, as follows: **1. Developing a control list** for identifying internal and external human rights and environmental risks. **2. Prioritising risks** as a function of their severity, probability and urgency. **3. Defining mitigating actions** as a function of the results of the monitoring effort. **4. Documenting the process**, defining the internal and external risks and providing training across the affected areas of the firm and to third parties. **5. Integrating human rights and environmental risks** into the overall supply chain risk map with a view to subsequently controlling them. ESG aspects are playing an increasingly important role in that process. ### **Supplier audits** CIE Automotive assesses its suppliers' financial health in order to ensure their ability to deliver throughout the duration of its projects. Supplier evaluations take the form of process audits that assess and score them on several parameters, including planning, reception, training and skills, process, maintenance, inspection, packaging, storage, continuous improvement and environmental performance, customer satisfaction, documentation and ESG criteria. The results of the audits may be shared with the supplier. On other occasions it is the supplier that conducts a self-assessment which is then corroborated by qualified CIE Automotive professionals. Thanks to this system of self-assessment and onsite audits, in 2023 the company conducted 698\* audits, compared to 582 in 2022, an increase of 20%. In 2024, the group has set itself the target of increasing that figure by 10%, stepping up the number of onsite audits in particular. ### *External verification of ESG health using artificial intelligence* Between self-assessments and onsite audits, **in 2023 the company conducted 698 audits, growth of 20% from 2022** In 2023, CIE Automotive reached an agreement with the one of world's most important ESG ratings companies for the verification of supplier ESG compliance covering over 50% of its global procurement spend. The scope of this exercise, which began in 2022 when it was associated exclusively with governance considerations, has been widened to include: • The Red Flags Grid (fines, human rights, environment, business l predictive - conduct, corporate governance) - Country risk - Default risk - ESG scoring: analytic and predictive - Scope1 & 2 emissions The information provided by this rating company, which uses artificial intelligence and internal and external databases to check the suppliers' information, allows the group to contrast and complement the information it obtains from its Suppliers Portal. By way of conclusion, just 3 of all the suppliers evaluated presented risks in any of the above-listed areas; an action plan has been established to monitor their progress and the company is searching for alternative for these suppliers in the event the risks cannot be addressed. *(\*) One of them was carried out in the business of discontinued German forging companies.* Chairman and CEO's [statement](#page-2-0) **2023 [highlights](#page-5-0)** **Ready [for change](#page-15-0)** **Record [earnings](#page-53-0)** **Common responsibility, [shared benefits](#page-64-0)** **Our response to [the environmental](#page-141-0) challenge Responsible [management](#page-183-0)** About [this report](#page-229-0) [Data tables](#page-261-0) **1** **2** **3** **4** **5** **6** Image /page/132/Picture/25 description: The image shows the CIE Automotive logo. The reasons for not continuing downstream to the end of the products' useful life are multiple and are related with the supply and supplier structure in the automotive sector: - In most of our sales agreements with customers, it is the customer who is tasked with collecting the product at the CIE Automotive factory in question, using its own logistics flows, over which CIE Automotive has neither control, responsibility or information. - The OEMs work around platforms. In other words, a given part is used in different models, with different characteristics and, therefore, different emissions. In addition, a given part of the propulsion or transmission system is used in different models, making it impossible to determine its performance in use. - Lastly, the vehicles assembled by the OEMs are, often, supplied to different countries and markets with totally different end-of-life regulations and strategies. CIE Automotive has no control over that distribution and therefore is not able to calculate the footprint associated with this step in its products' life cycle. CIE Automotive's customers ask it for environmental footprint data up to the company's gates and include those figures in their full measurements with the rest of the downstream phases without any double counting. The company uses the ReCIPE life cycle impact methodology to calculate its environmental footprint, to which end it is receiving assistance from the Basque regional government's environmental management company, IHOBE. Within the universe of activities of each company, based on the assessment that their impact is smaller, the following aspects were excluded from the analysis: #### **Upstream** - Consumption at central/sales offices outside of manufacturing facilities. - Capital goods (vehicles, machinery, tools, etc.). - Displacement of employees to go to work. - Business travel. - Upstream assets leased. - Trips to the organisation by visitors or customers. #### **Downstream** - Transport and distribution. - Processing of products sold. - Use of products sold. - End-of-life treatment of products sold. - Assets leased in subsequent phases. - Franchises. - Investments. ## To calculate the environmental footprint, **the company uses the ReCIPE methodology and has the collaboration of IHOBE** The downstream exclusions are not really exclusions as they are not included in CIE Automotive's footprint scope (from cradle to gate) for the reasons itemised earlier and in order to prevent double counting by the customer, who is the party with the information and responsibility for the downstream phases of our production. The company currently uses widely acknowledged databases such as Ecoinvent. For its electricity emissions factors, it uses updated databases in each country where it consumes electricity. One of the goals of the Supply Chain Race 2 Zero project is to compile real information about each significant product or service directly from our suppliers. However, the large majority of our suppliers are not yet prepared to provide robust, real data that they can regularly update. Note that a one-off figure is not sufficient; supplier emissions information needs to be updated as they advance on their decarbonisation and emissions-abatement plans. This is part of the coaching and mentoring work we are doing under the umbrella of this supplier programme. In 2023 surveys were undertaken in at least two factories per region in order to assess the volume of emissions associated with employee commutes to work. The analysis performed in 2023, such that the calculations are based on emissions data for 2022, indicate commute-related emissions ranging from 3.10% of the total in Europe to 0.11% in Asia. | | Chairman

The use of water at its factories is not relevant by comparison with other manufacturing industries. Although the company has a clear commitment to reducing water consumption as a general KPI, the ratio of water consumption per product made is actually very low. In order to minimise water discharges, the company has proprietary water treatment systems that enable its recirculation and recovery. The wastewater that reaches public treatment plants through wastewater pipes has therefore already been treated by the company. One of the circular transition indicators calculated by CIE Automotive is the volume of water reused in the production facilities. That recirculation is concentrated primarily in the refrigeration circuits. Water consumption totalled 1,625,246.72 megalitres/year in 2023, and water intensity was 0.40, compared to 0.41 in 2022. The CAPEX and OPEX related with water are very low and are not subject to any specific monitoring. However, the company does have several water minimisation projects underway in collaboration with customers, related for example with dry machining. Under development --- # Climate risk map ### **RISK MAPPING: PROCEDURE AND SCOPE** In response to demands from our stakeholders and in line with the 2025 Strategic Plan, in 2023, CIE Automotive updated and broadened its climate risk map, a process which involved a bigger number of its professionals. Specifically, in 2023, the company assessed 12 risks, gathering input from 145 professionals in total. The climate risk map is integrated within CIE Automotive's enterprise risk management (ERM) system, which follows ISO 31000 methodology, so as to provide reasonable assurance that all significant climate risks are duly identified, evaluated, prevented and continuously monitored. Those risks are approved at the board level and managed in keeping with defined risk tolerance thresholds. The climate risk assessment contemplates transition and physical risks and also focuses on the opportunities that climate change could generate. The accompanying chart depicts the classification of risks and opportunities considered in this process so that they can be assessed, including their financial impact, and subsequently managed and mitigated. The process of measuring the financial impact of these risks is currently under development so as to cater to the needs and requirements brought to us by our stakeholders in recent years and those we expect to face in the coming years. The process also considers qualitative variables derived from sector analyses and studies sourced from organisations such as ACICAE, SERNAUTO and EGVIA, and from public and private studies by different consultancy firms and analysts who collaborate with CIE Automotive. Based on this information, the Environment Department selects and describes the risks identified as most material for the company. The entire process is supervised by the governance layer outlined above. To categorise the risks, the organisation identifies key individuals with different backgrounds and duties and deep knowledge and involvement at the local or factory levels and at the country or regional levels and at the overall group level. Once the weightings are applied, the climate risk map takes shape *[refer to section "Climate risks evaluated in 20223"]* and the corresponding mitigation measures are presented and duly and coherently associated with the Strategic Plan, which is available on the website in both standard format and in the form of streamed presentation by management. A detailed procedure is being drawn up for tackling physical risks so as to consider exposure and vulnerability separately (this aspect was prioritised in 2023). Adaptability criteria will be layered in subsequently to create a ranking of risks and the last step will be to assess the financial impact of the various climate risks. Note that the financial impact assessment aspect has yet to be comprehensively regulated so that this process will also need to factor in the definitive regulations.
