As a result, some technologies could lose share in the overall business mix, potentially intensifying competition for the remaining volumes and, by extension, driving a reduction in volumes or margins in certain products or technologies. It is still too early to tell when the automotive sector will revisit prepandemic production and sales levels, all the more so considering the various market developments mentioned throughout this report and the fact that market changes are currently unfolding with such great speed. The company plans to reinforce the flexibility of its model to adapt to unfolding and future customer needs and emerging trends. Product portfolio diversification will give it a unique ability to adapt relative to its competitors. A portfolio in which more than eight out of every 10 products are independent of a vehicle's propulsion system and therefore not impacted by the sector electrification trend. For the rest of its parts, the company is working from the technological and market standpoints to make the most of the opportunities emerging in the battery, engine/motor, power electronics and gearshift areas. As for the risk associated with products for which there is no clear substitute in zero-emission cars, CIE Automotive plans to increase its presence in those that have a bigger role to play in the vehicle light-weighting trend (forged chassis and suspension parts) and in machined shafts and gears. It also wants to actively pursue business in technologies that customers are likely to outsource in order to focus on new challenges, such as connectivity, automated driving and the provision of embedded software solutions. In parallel, the company will continue to focus on its innovation effort in these same areas which is expected to give the company a winning edge in the coming years, positioning it to take advantage of the opportunity to consolidate the resulting market. The transition towards a low-carbon economy will highlight the efforts companies like CIE Automotive have been making for years to introduce eco-design concepts from the earliest stages of product development and build circularity into all of their processes. What does look likely is that over a medium-term horizon the automotive companies stand to emerge stronger from the crisis to the extent they can adapt to the new scenario, foreseeably characterised by the following factors, on which CIE Automotive is already specifically working: • Concentration processes: fewer players but companies that are larger, more diversified and more resilient in the face of future - Reduction of surplus capacity. - crises. - prepare for sector transformation. - Greater financial control and discipline. - Eco-efficiency and circularity. - Commitment to mitigating environmental impacts. • Strategic alliances designed to share the investment needed to CIE Automotive's business model has already proven its resilience and counter-cyclical credentials in the face of numerous crises thanks to the combination of geographic, technological and customer diversification, framed by a decentralised management model and strict financial discipline. Manufacturing technology is what CIE Automotive does. That is why it is essential to monitor how it evolves, that being one of the most recurring and important tasks performed by each division. Thanks to that constant monitoring, the company sees a bright future for the technologies it is active in. In some of those technologies, the challenge lies with taking advantage of the growth opportunities being thrown up by emerging trends; in others, they key lies with maximising competitiveness by leveraging innovation, Industry 4.0 tools and the cost efficiency that sets the group apart. The goal of the new text is once again to ensure that the remuneration earned by CIE Automotive's directors is proportionate to the dedication and responsibilities assumed and aligned with market practices at comparable companies in Spain and abroad and with the long-term interests of all of the company's shareholders. #### **Director remuneration** Although the new Director Remuneration Policy is similar in structure to the outgoing policy, there have been a few changes. The terms of the long-term bonus tied to the company's share price performance accrued by the CEO have been adjusted to reflect the radical change in the socio-economic context and the company's share price performance since 2018, when the bonus was approved. The Director Remuneration Policy stipulates that the fixed annual stipend for directors shall only be paid to non-executive directors that are particularly dedicated to the company, i.e., the chairman of the Board of Directors and the independent directors. The ceiling on director remuneration was increased at the 2023 AGM. As under the outgoing policy, the full-time executive directors' remuneration regime is similar to that of the company's executives. Their remuneration comprises: fixed remuneration, a short-term, results-based bonus and, in the case of the CEO, a longterm bonus, conditional upon staying in the post for 10 years. The executive directors may also receive in-kind remuneration in the form of use of a company car. The remuneration earned by the executive directors varies along with their responsibilities and the specific characteristics of the duties they perform and is reviewed annually by the Board of Directors at the recommendation of the Appointments and Remuneration Committee. It is up to the Board of Directors, at the recommendation of the Appointments and Remuneration Committee (based on prior verification of attainment of the established targets), to determine the level of delivery of the short-term bonuses and their amount. The executive directors' remuneration may be topped up by health and life insurance, in line with market practice at comparable companies in terms of market capitalisation, size, ownership structure and international presence. It should be noted that the variable remuneration of the group formed by the most important members of the Group's management includes a % of it linked to ESG performance. On the right side of the image is a large number 23. {201}------------------------------------------------ ### *A cutting-edge platform for the Whistleblowing Channel* CIE Automotive has mechanisms, protocols and tools for enabling and facilitating the notification of wrongdoings or unethical behaviour at the company or breaches of its Code of Conduct. In 2023 it reinforced this internal reporting channel by integrating an IT platform into its corporate website to secure the reporting process and simplify case management by the company. This cutting-edge platform is user-friendly and available in all the languages of the company's markets. If gives users the possibility of opening up a secure communication channel for filing a report and providing additional information in different formats (in writing, voice messages, etc.). All of the information is confidential and if the whistleblower so wishes, anonymous. The new online channel meets all the stipulations of Spanish Law 2/2023, of 20 February 2023, on the protection of persons reporting regulatory breaches and incidents of corruption and aligned with applicable international legal requirements derived from the European Whistleblowing Directive. Adaptation for this new piece of legislation has involved modification of the Whistleblowing Channel Rules, which set down the system's general principles and procedures. In 2023 the company received 56 complaints through its Whistleblowing Channel, 21 more than in 2022. Those complaints were related with: - People management with respect to work scheduling for everyday factory work purposes (20 complaints). - Workplace harassment (16): inappropriate attitudes on the part of managers vis-a-vis factory workers. - Fraud and corruption (seven): malpractice at several factories by procurement, engineering and production staff who breached CIE Automotive's general purchasing terms for their own benefit. Although the amounts involved were not material and the scale of the contracts with the suppliers in question did not have a material impact on earnings at the factories involved, the events harmed the group's image and violated its ethics commitment. - Breach of the Code of Professional Conduct (six): failure on the part of certain employees to uphold the rules of conduct. - Business management (four): related with the company's dealings with its stakeholders. - Discrimination (two): failure to guarantee equal opportunities. - Sexual harassment (one): inappropriate attitudes on the part of managers vis-a-vis factory workers. In 2022, by comparison, the reports were related with workplace harassment (13), people management with respect to work scheduling (nine), fraud and corruption (five), sexual harassment (three), business management (two), breaches of the Code of Professional Conduct (two) and discrimination (one). In all of the cases reported in 2023 and notified to the ESG Committee, the opportune actions were taken to analyse, monitor and remedy or close the cases. Those actions included nine dismissals: three related with the cases of fraud and corruption reported, two with the Code of Professional Conduct breaches, two with the business management cases, as well as one person who participated in the workplace harassment cases and one person involved in the discrimination reports. In addition, executives and HR professionals intervened to address the workplace and sexual harassment and discrimination reports and prevent their recurrence via enhanced education on the company's values and Code of Professional Conduct rules. The automotive industry is undergoing disruptive changes for which the company needs to be prepared by maintaining the flexibility required to adapt to customers' unfolding or future demands, suppliers' needs and increasingly stringent regulations. New automotive technologies (e.g. in the area of connectivity and autonomous driving) are reducing demand for some of our core products while creating demand for new systems and parts. *[For more detailed information about the key market trends, refer to chapter 2. Sector background]* Throughout the pages of this report, the reader has been told about CIE Automotive's distinctive business model which has proven highly consistent in dynamic and challenging environments over the past several years and is expected to remain similarly resilient in the face of the challenges that loom. The key to tackling the current trend shifts lies with coordinating all of the group's departments end to end. The unit that handles R&D and market studies analyses the trends that are shaping the sector exhaustively and continually (for more information, refer to chapter 2.1.3) and shares its findings with the sales area and the various divisions. That enables an informed assessment of their potential impact and formulation of the action plans that the company has been feeding into its strategic plans since 2015. That assessment also factors in the challenges highlighted in chapter 2, specifically: - Economic slowdown. - Increase in borrowing costs. - Significant CAPEX in EVs. - Price war in EVs. This process also taps the opportunities itemised in that same chapter. Collaboration on R&D projects, sometimes on a standalone basis and other times in partnership with customers, has proven crucial in areas such as electrification, the circular economy, vehicle light-weighting, safety and Industry 4.0. These projects have led to major collaboration with traditional customers and kept the company aligned with market trends. In tandem the sales area has worked intensely to penetrate the sector's newcomers, adapting its approach to their idiosyncrasies. This effort has paid off with the company already producing at scale for customers with business models that are radically different from those of its traditional customer base and new developments in the pipeline. The company has also responded proactively to the growing importance of climate action, as is evident in its unification of the engineering and environmental departments. As a result it now builds sustainability, decarbonisation, circular economy and ecodesign considerations in at the earliest stages of new product and project development. Framed by those legislative requirements, CIE Automotive has defined a control structure made up of: (i) the Board of Directors, as the highest decision-making body; (ii) the Audit and Compliance Committee, as oversight and control body; and (iii) the Support Unit. CIE Automotive has vested the control and oversight duties in the Audit and Compliance Committee, as it has the autonomy and independence in terms of control powers and the ability to act required under the control framework. The Compliance Department is responsible for continuously reviewing and updating the internal control system and ensuring compliance with internal and external regulations and the policies and procedures in place for mitigating the main corruption and fraud risks. It is also in charge of the Model and establishment, development and updating CIE Automotive's ethics framework. All of CIE Automotive factories use an IT tool to guarantee performance of the required internal controls. That tool is the SAP GRC (Governance, Risk and Compliance) suite, which permits the automated and manual analysis of the level of performance of the controls conducted at the factory level and tracks incidents and any resulting action plans, enabling traceability, as outlined in greater detail in the Internal Control Systems section. New internal controls were launched in 2023 to mitigate some of the main criminal risks identified in the regions with a tailored risk map and training was undertaken in the following areas: • Corporate liability and anti-corruption, launched between the end of 2020 and 2021, provided to 600 people in total, including the company's directors, key management personnel, the global management team and the members of the local management committees. Since then, all newcomers to those groups have also been receiving the corporate liability and anti-corruption training. • Code of Professional Conduct, provided to over 6,000 people online in 2021 and to the rest of CIE Automotive's people worldwide in the form of brochures and a final assessment. • ESG training, provided to over 6,500 people online in 2023 and to the rest of CIE Automotive's people worldwide in the form of brochures - - - and a final assessment. With process mining, aided by artificial intelligence, it is possible to quickly visualise, identify and quantify bottlenecks and inefficiencies across the business, so delivering the following benefits, among others: - Increased efficiency by removing bottlenecks, improving cycle times and streamlining processes. - Cost reduction associated with duplicity, rework and manual processes. - Improved compliance by detecting non-compliant processes or possible cases fraud. - ¡Continuous business optimisation by improving processes and monitoring them in real-time. In 2023, with the aim of making the company's internal control system more efficient, CIE Automotive embarked on a process mining project with Celonis (the tool provider) and the consultancy, Deloitte. The goal of this project is to establish use cases that, by interconnecting all of the company's ERPs around the world, help generate value in the company's business processes by detecting inefficiencies and optimising processes. In short, the idea is to improve processes by detecting bottlenecks, identifying the best routes to achieving a given objective, as well as flagging any potential cases of fraud. . This translates into the establishment of numerical indicators and scorecards that make it easier for the business and corporate managers to understand and monitor the data. In 2023 the company managed to implement process mining in the production SAP environments in Europe and at Datasul in Brazil and the tool is under development in the S/4 HANA environment of the roof systems division (with global reach) and the SAP environments in Mexico, India and in other environments in Europe. Throughout the entire process of collecting and presenting its financial and non-financial information, CIE Automotive bears in mind the principles of transparency, materiality, comparability, timeliness, clarity and reliability needed to assure the quality of the information reported. The techniques used to measure and calculate the data provided, along with any estimates made, are explained in the corresponding tables or chapters of the report as necessary to facilitate reader comprehension. #### **Non-financial reporting process** This report, which is appended to the consolidated management report as a separate document, includes constitutes CIE Automotive's 2023 non-financial statement (NFS) and provides information about the environmental, social and governance (ESG) activities of CIE Automotive S.A. and its investees during the year across the 18 countries where it does business. The Chinese joint venture, SAMAP, is excluded from the scope as it is accounted for using the equity method. However, in order to confirm that, despite being an equity-accounted investee, the ESG risks to which the group is exposed through its joint venture in China are not material for CIE Automotive, a self-assessment was conducted on the basis of the contents of Spanish Law 11/2018 on non-financial and diversity reporting. That assessment revealed the existence of a working methodology at the joint venture around ESG matters, with specific targets and indicators, that is aligned with CIE Automotive's methodology. The non-financial disclosures were prepared in keeping with Spanish Law 11/2018 and the non-binding guidelines on nonfinancial reporting issued by the European Commission on 5 July 2017 (EU Guidelines 2017/C 215/01) and the GRI Standards. The non-financial statement, which is part of this Annual Report, was assured KPMG Auditores, S.L., which also audited the group's annual financial statements. The Audit and Compliance Committee is tasked with ensuring that firm's independence. The non-financial information, which is part of the NFS, included in this report was compiled with the input and oversight of the heads of all of the various departments and areas: - The Compliance Department is ultimately responsible for its preparation and coordination, albeit ably assisted by the Cross-Group ESG Committee. - The Board of Directors is ultimately responsible for approving its issue, along with the management report. The Board of Directors is kept regularly abreast of the most significant environmental, social and governance matters by the ESG Committee. To round out the information about the group's activities throughout the year, a number of other statutory reports are available for download on the corporate website: separate and consolidated annual financial statements and management report, Annual Corporate Governance Report and Annual Report on Board Remuneration, along with all of the presentations published about different aspects of the group or in the specific website tabs devoted to specific stakeholder groups. Our firm applies International Standard on Quality Management 1 (ISQM1), which requires the firm to design, implement and operate a quality management system that include policies and procedures regarding compliance with ethical requirements, professional standards and applicable legal and regulatory requirements. The engagement team was comprised of professionals specialised in reviews of non-financial information and, specifically, in information on economic, social and environmental performance. #### **Our Responsibility \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_** Our responsibility is to express our conclusions in an independent limited assurance report based on the work performed. We conducted our engagement in accordance with the requirements of the Revised International Standard on Assurance Engagements 3000, "Assurance Engagements other than Audits or Reviews of Historical Financial Information" (ISAE 3000 (Revised)), issued by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB) of the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC), and with the guidelines for assurance engagements on the Non-Financial Information Statement issued by the Spanish Institute of Registered Auditors (ICJCE). The procedures performed in a limited assurance engagement vary in nature and timing from, and are less in extent than for, a reasonable assurance engagement, and consequently, the level of assurance provided is also lower. Our work consisted of making inquiries of management, as well as of the different units and areas of the Group that participated in the preparation of the NFIS, reviewing the processes for compiling and validating the information presented in the NFIS and applying certain analytical procedures and sample review tests, which are described below: Image /page/249/Figure/2 description: The image shows the first page of a report. The report also includes a section about the report itself. - Meetings with the Group's personnel to gain an understanding of the business model, policies and management approaches applied, the principal risks related to these matters and to obtain the information necessary for the external review. - Analysis of the scope, relevance and completeness of the content of the NFIS for 2023 based on the materiality analysis performed by the Group and described in the "Materiality" section of - "About this report", considering the content required by prevailing mercantile legislation. – Analysis of the processes for compiling and validating the data presented in the NFIS for 2023. #### 3 (Translation from the original in Spanish. Procurement of a representation letter from the Directors and management. #### **Conclusion \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_** Based on the assurance procedures performed and the evidence obtained, nothing has come to our attention that causes us to believe that the NFIS of CIE Automotive S.A. and subsidiaries for the year ended 31 December 2023, included in the accompanying Report, has not been prepared, in all material respects, in accordance with prevailing mercantile legislation and selected GRI Standards based on each subject area in the "Tracing compliance with Spain's Law on Non-Financial Information and Diversity reporting" table of the aforementioned Report. #### **Emphasis of Matter\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_** Regulation (EU) 2020/852 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 18 June 2020 on the establishment of a framework to facilitate sustainable investment, and the Delegated Acts adopted in accordance with this Regulation, stipulate the obligation to disclose information on how and to what extent the undertaking's activities are associated with eligible economic activities in relation to the environmental objectives of sustainable use and protection of water and marine resources, transition to a circular economy, pollution prevention and control and protection and restoration of biodiversity and ecosystems (the other environmental objectives), and with respect to certain new activities included in the climate change mitigation and climate change adaptation objectives, for the first time for the 2023 fiscal year, in addition to the information on eligible and aligned activities already required in 2022 in relation to the climate change mitigation and climate change adaptation objectives. Consequently, no comparative information on eligibility has been included in the accompanying Report in relation to the other environmental objectives listed above or to the new activities included in the climate change mitigation and climate change adaptation objectives. Furthermore, as much as the information on 2022 was not required to be as detailed as in 2023, the disclosures included in the accompanying Report are not strictly comparable. Additionally, the Directors of CIE Automotive, S.A. have included information on the criteria that, in their opinion, allow them to comply better with the aforementioned obligations, and which are defined in the "Compliance with Regulation (EU) 2020/852 regarding climate-related taxonomy" section of the accompanying Report. The text "CIE Automotive" is in a simple, sans-serif font. **Our response to the environmental challenge 5** : report es {2}------------------------------------------------ Dear friends of CIE Automotive: It is our pleasure to introduce CIE Automotive's Annual Report for 2023, a year in which we feel like we made a real difference and helped transform the world through our work. The following pages explain how we took decisions and how we embarked on pathways that not only served to consolidate our financial success but also impacted the people and organisations around us and will ultimately benefit society and the planet in the long term. We are living in challenging times: the sector is faced with making heavy investments to decarbonise vehicles and increase their connectivity and comfort; it is being drawn into a price war in the electric vehicle segment; and inflation and higher costs are putting pressure on our earnings. There are also, however, encouraging signs that we are on the cusp of a new automotive cycle. There is a dashed line through the middle of the number "2". {3}------------------------------------------------ Despite this uncertain climate, with its highlights and lowlights, in 2023 we once again marked new records in revenue, profitability and cash generation. We posted a net profit of €320.2 million, growth of 6.7% from 2022. Our bottom line was driven by topline growth of 3.1% to €3.96 billion and a stronger performance across all our markets, lifting the group's EBITDA to €713.2 million, implying a margin of 18.0%. We converted €447.4 million of that EBITDA into cash flow and brought our net debt down to €1.13 billion. In parallel, we paid our shareholders over €100 million, so delivering our commitment to paying out one-third of our net profit in dividends. As you can see, these are truly extraordinary numbers, especially considering the environment, which is why we want to thank and congratulate the entire CIE Automotive team for making them possible. We are optimistic about the future. We are ready to take advantage of the opportunities thrown up by the current market trends to surmount the challenges looming and continue to generate value for our shareholders, both through dividend payments and share price gains, as we have been doing for over 25 years. To do that, we have a unique business model, which has proven its worth in very tough times, articulated around six pillars: multiple locations, customer diversification, a multi-technology approach, disciplined investing, decentralised management and embedded sustainability standards. A model that will allow us to meet the ambitious targets set down in our 2025 Strategic Plan, which position us among the three most profitable automotive parts makers. With that in mind, in 2023 we redirected our financial and managerial resources to the businesses and markets offering most growth potential and highest returns. We acquired Iber-Oleff Brasil in a transaction that has reinforced our position in a growth market and allowed us to diversify our local customer base, and we sold our German forging factories specialised in the European truck market. Financial returns are not, however, our only ambition. Throughout last year we met all our compliance requirements and continued to engage all our professionals in the task of embedding ESG matters into our day-to-day operations. As signatories of the United Nations Global Compact, we aspire to contribute to delivery of the Sustainable Development Goals contemplated in the Agenda 2030 to end poverty, protect the planet and ensure that everyone can live in peace and prosperity. We are well aware that with 10 R&D centers and 108 plants in 17 countries, we are in a privileged position to do that. In 2023 we once again marked new records in revenue, profitability and cash generation. **We posted a net profit of €320.2 million, growth of 6.7% from 2022** ### Chairman and CEO's [statement](#page-2-0) **2023 [highlights](#page-5-0) Ready [for change](#page-15-0) Record [earnings](#page-53-0) Common responsibility, [shared benefits](#page-64-0) Our response to [the environmental](#page-141-0) challenge Responsible [management](#page-183-0)** About [this report](#page-229-0) [Data tables](#page-261-0) **1 2 3 4 5 6** Image /page/3/Picture/11 description: The image shows the CIE Automotive logo. It is thanks to their dedication that we were able to continue to grow in 2023, generate wealth and mobilise other people so that they too become agents of change. In exchange, we provided them with €35 million worth of support measures (health insurance, food, transportation, etc.) and offered them as safe, stimulating and fair a place to work as possible, regardless of where they carry out their work. We lifted the percentage of women in our workforce by two points and by year-end had completed diversity and inclusion assessments at 93% of our factories, generating action plans for including people of different cultures, genders, generations and abilities. This is a particularly important milestone in countries whose populations are not sensitive to these matters and where there is no legislation around them. Our responsible doings have a domino effect on our supply chain. In 2023, we renewed our ISO 20400 Sustainable Procurement certification and rolled out Supply Chain Race 2 Zero, our project for rallying our worldwide suppliers around our goal of being net zero by no later than 2050, offering them resources, guidance and environmental training. This initiative is part of our new environmental roadmap which echoes and expands on the targets set in our 2025 Strategic Plan and establishes new steps towards climate neutrality. Last year we accompanied our customers with their efforts to decarbonise transport by investing in technology projects aimed at reducing the weight of our parts and improving material circularity. We also participated in a number of research programmes related with the electrification of transport, including Basquevolt, the Basque alliance for the creation of solid-state lithium batteries. All these activities favour progress in society and development in our business communities, which we supported in 2023 by contributing €497 million of tax and participating in community projects that benefitted over 41,500 people, projects we are certain will have a multiplier effect in the long term. In 2023 we demonstrated that the future is not preordained, that it is our actions that mark the difference. We know that much remains to be done to create the fair, prosperous and sustainable world we all long for but we are convinced that we are taking steps in the right direction and that is something we are proud of. Inauguration of the company's first greenfield factory in Mexico, in the town of Celaya. #### **2006** Entry into the Chinese market, CIE Automotive's first Asian stop, with a greenfield project, CIE Automotive Parts Shanghai. Creation of the CIE Desc joint venture in Mexico, marking a qualitative leap in the ability to service North American customers. #### **2009** Entry into the roof systems segment with the acquisition of Advanced Comfort Systems (ACS). #### **2011** Reverse merger with Dominion via Inssec. CIE Autometal listed on the Sao Paulo stock exchange. ### **2012** Initial foray into the US market with the acquisition of Century Plastics. Maiden forging factory in Asia with the creation of the Nanjing Automotive Forging joint venture (NFJ). #### **2013** Entry into the Indian market via the strategic alliance with India's Mahindra & Mahindra Group, giving rise to MCIE (since renamed, CIE India), a listed company. ### **2014** Delisting of CIE Automotive's Brazilian subsidiary, Autometal. #### **2015** Endorsement of the United Nations Global Compact, approval of the group's CSR & Sustainability Policy and creation of the Cross-Group CSR Committee (currently, the Cross-Group ESG Committee). #### **2016** CIE Automotive lists its technology subsidiary, Dominion. #### **2017** Publication of the Global Supply Chain Manual. Celebration of the first CSR Day (currently called ESG Days). #### **2018** CIE Automotive's shares in Dominion distributed to the company's shareholders in the form of an extraordinary dividend. Creation of the Suppliers Portal as a management tool focused on overseeing ESG risks. #### **2019** Acquisition of Inteva's roof systems division, positioning CIE Automotive in the global top 3 in the design and manufacture of roofs. #### **2020** CIE Automotive ties its €690 million syndicated loan to green finance criteria. Membership of the SERNAUTO Responsible Business Committee. First share buyback and cancellation programme. #### **2021** CIE Automotive turns 25 and unveils its 2025 Strategic Plan. #### **2022** Commitment to achieve climate neutrality before 2050 announced. Second share buyback and cancellation programme. This permanent scrutiny allows it to mitigate the key market risks and leverage its competitive advantages.** Next is a description of the main challenges and opportunities, with further information provided in "Risk management - Market risks": ### **Economic slowdown** According to the International Monetary Fund's estimates, the global economy grew at a moderate rate of 3% in 2023 and will slow to 2.9% in 2024, well below the 3.5% recorded in 2022 and average growth of 3.8% between 2000 and 2019. Prospects are, however, very difference between the advanced economies, where the slowdown is expected to be more pronounced, and emerging and developing economies, which are expected to register higher growth. The euro symbol is a circle with a horizontal line through the center. #### **Heavy investment in electric vehicles** The transition to electric mobility is requiring heavy investments in new technology around batteries, vehicle autonomy and electric propulsion systems. The OEMs need to design specific vehicle platforms, requiring significant investment in engineering and design. Automotive suppliers need to improve their production lines to adapt them for electric vehicles which implies, in addition to capital expenditure, investing in skills. Image /page/19/Picture/30 description: The image shows a black circle with a white Euro symbol inside it. Above the circle is a black arrow pointing upwards. The background is a light peach color. ### **Increase in borrowing costs** The automotive sector players were faced by an increase in borrowing costs as a result of the successive interest rate increases implemented to curb inflation. The increase in the cost of money left many OEMs and suppliers, which had leveraged up to deal with the fallout from the pandemic and/or invest in vehicle electrification, in a precarious position. Image /page/19/Picture/15 description: The image shows a black and white icon of an electric car being charged. The car is depicted in silhouette with a charging cable plugged into its side. Above the car are two euro symbols with a lightning bolt in between them, suggesting the cost of electricity. The overall design is simple and graphic, likely intended for use as a symbol or sign related to electric vehicles and charging costs. . #### **Price war in electric vehicle segment** Growth in electric vehicles is driving the OEMs to cut prices aggressively in order build a position in the market. A price war broke out in January when one of the electric vehicle segment leaders cut the price of its cheaper models in a move that was quickly followed by the other OEMs, worried they would be left out of this niche; discounts went as high as 15% on some models in China. In fact, the Chinese electric vehicle makers are making major inroads, exporting very cheap models to Europe. ### **CHALLENGES** Despite the sector's strong performance in 2023 in the wake of global supply chain normalisation, the business faced certain challenges that could well become more pressing in the years to come: Image /page/19/Picture/7 description: The image shows a black and white icon of a euro symbol inside a circle. To the right of the words is a large number "23" with a gray quotation mark above it. {22}------------------------------------------------ Market performance by region #### **Europe:** Production in Europe totalled 17.3 million vehicles in 2023, annual growth of 12.6%, reflecting the gradual supply chain normalisation. In 2023, purchases were boosted by the need to renew an aged vehicle fleet (especially rental car fleets) and electric and plug-in purchase incentives. In the electric segment the European OEMs are facing a surge in Chinese electric vehicle imports. The resulting price war is putting the weaker parts suppliers in a tough situation, negotiating prices that leave their EBIT margins at under 5%. Faced by this situation, while Brussels has officially started an anti-subsidy investigation on electric cars from China, the various national governments are rolling out initiatives to protect their industries. For this and other strategic reasons, the Chinese OEMs are looking into options for setting up manufacturing in Europe down the line. For example, in December BYD formally announced plans to build a factory in Hungary in phases. The Europe coming year losing share The European market is forecast to remain flat in the coming years, as is expected of a mature market that is losing share to other areas of the world. ### **North America:** Vehicle production in North America totalled 15.7 million units, up 9.7% from 2022. This growth, considered high for a mature market, is attributable to the positive impact of the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), which provides electric vehicle buyers a tax credit of up to \$7,500 if the car meets certain regional production requirements. A flat evolution is expected in the coming years, typical of an already mature market that is losing weight in favor of other markets. One negative development was the simultaneous strike at three OEMs - General Motors, Stellantis and Ford - in the US and Canada. Production foregone during the stoppages is estimated at 203,793 vehicles. Unlike Europe and despite the market's maturity, vehicle production in the US is expected to increase by 1% in 2024, in large part, but not entirely, due to the recovery in volumes in the wake of the strike. Medium term, the market is expected to revisit its pre-pandemic levels by 2026, again setting it apart from the European market. ### *Vehicle purchase incentives* In August 2022, the US passed the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), which includes \$369bn in clean energy investments as well as provisions that will lower the cost of prescription drugs and increase taxes on large corporations. Of particular interest for the automotive sector is the vehicle purchase incentive and the infrastructure tax credit. Overall, the bill is projected to help cut greenhouse gas emissions by about 40% from 2005 levels by the end of the decade. The Inflation Reduction Act contains financial incentives to encourage the purchase of electric and hydrogen fuel cell powered vehicles as well as the deployment of charging stations. Provisions in the IRA provide a tax credit for the purchase of the vehicle itself and a tax credit for the purchase and installation of charging assets or charging infrastructure. Tax breaks mitigated the pronounced rise in interest rates in 2023. The big announcement last year was BYD's acquisition of the old Ford factory in Bahía, which is now expected to produce two electric cars and one hybrid model, as well as electric trucks and buses. Production is expected to start in the second half of 2024 with initial annual capacity of 150,000 units, a figure expected to double to 300,000 from 2025. Growth in production is expected to accelerate in 2024, to 3% and, most notably in 2025 and 2026, when production growth is forecast at 6% and 7%, respectively. Some of the anticipated growth is attributable to the fact that the Brazilian central bank has already started to cut interest rates. #### **India:** Demand for vehicles in India broke new records in 2023. Production increased by 4.4% to 5.4 million units, despite strong levels already in 2022. As well as a strong performance in the passenger vehicle segment, other segments with even greater growth potential started to recover: commercial vehicles (+0%); motorcycles (+4%) and tractors (-2%). Notably electrification also started to make inroads in this market: in early October, Tata announced it would launch eight electric models in 2030. This growth is expected to get a further injection from public initiatives designed to draw investments related with electric vehicles. In 2023, electric car sales volumes increased by around 90% (88% as of November). However, combustion-engine vehicles are expected to continue to dominate this market. As for the outlook for light vehicle production, growth is expected to take a breather in 2024, consolidating the sharp growth recorded last year before going on to regain traction, with growth of 4/5% forecast for both 2025 and 2026. ### **China:** The world's largest vehicle maker increased production by 10.0% in 2023. Although domestic demand appears to be slowing, Chinese production was boosted by the extension of tax relief for electric vehicles until 2027. Moreover, the Chinese OEMs are growing in foreign markets thanks to a price-based growth strategy. Annual growth to 2026 is forecast at 3%. Climate change regulations are tackling two key fronts. Firstly, they are requiring the use of greener energy sources, focused primarily on electrification. Secondly, all sector players must mitigate their carbon footprints taking a lifecycle approach. ### **Demographic trends** There are many opposing demographic trends unfolding simultaneously around the world whose ultimate overall effect on the automotive sector is expected to be clearly positive. - More than half of forecast population growth is concentrated in Africa, but the most of the world's population is located in Asia (60%), with Europe losing share (10%.) - Life expectancies are rising and birth rates dropping, driving population ageing. - Urbanisation is a parallel trend and we are also seeing - mainly regional - migratory displacements of populations. #### **Technological change** The world is moving towards a Fourth Industrial Revolution, which will change our lives and make productive processes, including those of the automotive sector, more efficient. The emerging improved and more efficient vehicle architectures are based on the use of the right materials and their correct application, which means that different technologies will have a role to play in the next-generation, multi-material vehicles. ### **Macroeconomics and geopolitics** - Emerging market opportunities: the Chinese, Indian and Brazilian economies, to name a few, are expected to experience sharp growth in the coming years. - National protectionism: initially perceived as a threat, protectionism strategies are no longer expected to have a significant impact on the automotive sector. Nowadays they are looking for aspects related with comfort, such as spaciousness, driver assistance and smart infrastructure, to the detriment of other attributes such as power, aerodynamics and external aesthetics. Within the comfort thrust, the penetration of roof systems is outpacing the general automotive market. ### **Safety and protection** Vehicle safety prioritisation is making manufacturing more complex and increasing the number of parts and their added value. Today's cars are being fitted with sophisticated driver assistance systems that prevent accidents and other passive safety systems designed to mitigate damage and injuries in the event of a collision; those systems are being embedded in the chassis and bodywork, for example, as well as shaping seatbelt and airbag development. Growing safety and protection requirements for passengers and other road users is requiring the introduction of more complex solutions involving different materials, reinforcing the astuteness of the multitechnology approach. #### **Autonomous and connected car** Major progress has been made on autonomous driving in recent years, thanks to which important driver assistance features have been introduced to new cars. However, the mainstreaming of the autonomous car in the coming years continues to face obstacles. In parallel, users are demanding greater connectivity between their cars and the outside world (virtual assistants, automation, etc.), all of which requires establishing high-speed connections. The number 23 is large and bold, and there is a dashed line underneath it. **REPORT** {37}------------------------------------------------ ## Social responsibility at CIE Automotive **CIE Automotive factors ESG considerations into all its business decisions, from strategic planning to execution on the ground. This approach allows it to respond to its customers' demands and the growing body of legislation around sustainability, while also locking in profitable, long-term growth by driving efficiency and innovation so as to minimise its negative impacts.** ### **Global Compact** CIE Automotive's public commitment to sustainable development dates back to 2015, when it signed its endorsement of the United Nations Global Compact. That endorsement implied the public assumption of responsibility in key areas including human and labour rights, environmental protection and anti-corruption. Eight years later, as a Signatory of the Spanish Chapter of the Global Compact, the group has moved beyond its respect for the Company's 10 universally recognised principles and become an agent of systematic change in the shift towards a sustainable economy. This policy defines the fundamental principles and general framework for building sustainability practices into the company's business model and strategy. Effective application of these principles and the potential risks associated with it are addressed in CIE Automotive's Risk Management and Control Policy. ### **Management monitoring** Supervision of ESG and sustainability management falls to the Board of Director's ESG Committee, which delegates oversight of application of the principles in the Cross-Group ESG Committee. This monitoring process takes the form of 79 ESG indicators that measure performance in different areas. The KPIs are in turn included in each factory's management plans and are used to track delivery of the sustainability aspects of the 2025 Strategic Plan. These lines of initiative likewise respond to the market changes identified as a risk factor, as detailed in the "Risk management" chapter. **Electrification** The company wants to take advantage of the opportunity afforded by decarbonisation of the transport sector to create new value-added products for electric vehicles, particularly in EV motors, power electronics, gearboxes and batteries. At present, 80% of the products made by CIE Automotive are compatible with both electrified and combustionpowered vehicles. #### **Industry 4.0** Immersed in the fourth industrial revolution, CIE Automotive is gradually adopting smart manufacturing tools and different enabling technologies. These tools interact with and learn from each other and feature sensorisation capabilities that make it possible to capture data which is later analysed using algorithms. Implementation of these technologies is not only making our processes more efficient but is also reducing our environmental impact by cutting prototype volumes, energy and raw material consumption, product rejects and scrap generation. #### **International expansion** The company seeks geographical diversification by investing in countries where vehicle penetration is low and growth expectations are high. Broadly speaking, until 2025, the plan is for all the divisions to add capacity and develop new products that add more value and address their existing customers' emerging needs. In parallel, the sales teams are working intensely to bring in new customers. #### **Comfort** CIE Automotive's strategy in the comfort area is concentrated at its roof systems division. More specifically, it is looking to consolidate its position in bottomloaded roofs and fixed glass roofs with shades. It also wants to be able to incorporate panoramic roofs into both fixed and movable sunroofs, addressing all ranges. The company is also focusing on thinner roofs equipped with flat roller blind technology, which are particularly necessary in the electric vehicle segment. Lastly, it is working on ambient comfort by adding spot lighting to both its roofs and their shades. Image /page/42/Picture/20 description: The image shows the logo for CIE Automotive. In parallel, the company is working on projects in the electric motor, battery and power electronics systems in order to continue to penetrate the electrified vehicle segment and so contribute to the decarbonisation of transportation in the use phase. CIE Automotive collaborates with a range of research programmes targeting decarbonisation at both the regional and international levels. Those programmes are looking at systems for zero-emission vehicles, whether battery-powered or fuel-cell electric vehicles. In batteries, CIE Automotive is also participating in the Basque initiative for the production of solid-state batteries, which is planning to build 10 GWh of capacity. Basquevolt plans to commission a production line in four years' time, entailing €700 million of investment and generating more than 800 direct jobs. Solid-state batteries will deliver a substantial increase in battery autonomy, while lowering their costs and reducing dependence on certain critical materials. That will also lead to democratisation of the electric vehicle, paving the way for costs of €15,000 per vehicle, making them accessible to most citizens. Faced with higher borrowing costs on the back of successive interest rate increases, which put the weakest suppliers in serious jeopardy, the company locked in the liquidity and term structure needed by refinancing its debt and increasing the share of its borrowings at fixed rates to 54.5%. In parallel, it continued to honour its sustainability commitments by tying its borrowing costs to delivery of those pledges.** CIE Automotive's net debt came down by approximately €143.5 million in 2023 for an adjusted year-end balance of €1.13 billion, implying a net debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 1.56x. That leaves the company in a comfortable position for undertaking new strategic investments designed to further its profitable growth and reinforce its position in highgrowth markets. This moderate performance contrasts with stronger gains in the Stoxx Europe 600 Automobiles & Parts (+19%) and Ibex 35 (+23%), due, in part, to a more stringent base effect in the case of the company's shares. Over the past five years, CIE Automotive's share price has increased by 20%, significantly outperforming the Stoxx Europe 600 Automobiles & Parts (which gained 2% over that timeframe) and the Ibex 35 (just 1%). Comparing CIE Automotive's share price with the corrections sustained by most of the parts makers included in the broader sector index, the difference is even more striking. Over the course of 2023, however, there continued to be a lag between CIE Automotive's fundamentals and its share price performance. Specifically, its share price remained well below the consensus target price of €31.38 assigned by the universe of analysts that follow the company. In contrast to other automotive parts makers, the company has not had to issue any profit warnings in the face of the recent sector complexity, remaining among the top three sector players in terms of profitability and growth prospects. However, these achievements have not been priced in by the market. The automotive industry is not currently attractive to investors and mediumcap stocks are not managing to attract funds from the major investment funds, a combination that is not helping CIE Automotive. On top of this, liquidity fell in 2022, particularly after the company exited the Ibex 35 index. The company's share price performance over the last year should not cloud its performance over a longer time horizon. Under this programme, projects are being ranked by geography for close monitoring. Last year the company also organised internal communication seminars, shared best practices and developed new procedures for scaling up incidents with the goal of avoiding not only legal noncompliance but indeed any source of customer dissatisfaction. The company focused on the prevention of possible defects, an effort that included the reinforcement of procedures and controls, enhanced traceability of all products, analysis of the causes of potential defects and constant communication with its customers. Customer satisfaction is one of CIE's key success factors. To that end, the company has a satisfaction control system that measures, tracks and analyses customer feedback with the aim of proposing improvements at the various factories, where needed. This system is used to assess each factory's performance and to quantify customer perceptions on the basis of audits, assessments and current data. That information is then used to compile an annual report and draw up corrective action plans as necessary. ### **Consumer claims, complaints and grievance systems** Despite its best efforts on the product quality front, both preventive during the design and industrialisation phases and corrective during manufacturing, on occasion deviations lead to customer claims. When that happens, it is vital to react immediately to prevent the supply of nonconforming parts and conduct in-depth analysis of the root causes. The solutions provided are shared with and applied to all potentially affected facilities and technologies. The company did not receive any significant fines or penalties as a result of legal proceedings related with incidents of noncompliance with product information or labelling in 2023. CIE Automotive's predominantly male workforce is attributable to tradition in the automotive sector and restrictions on women accessing technical training at schools and universities. Thanks to this initiative, young professionals from different plants and of different nationalities attend an excellence training centre in the Basque region before going on to build their skills at the group's emblematic factories in Spain and Italy. This programme delivers four key objectives: embedding the group's values; facilitating cross-country communication going forward; fostering intragroup relationships; and providing the group with highly skilled professionals. Since resuming the programme in the wake of the pandemic, it has been expanded to the point of exceeding the Strategic Plan target. This protocol addresses the prevention of mobbing and of sexual or gender harassment and includes several preventive measures, such as zero-tolerance towards harassment, shared employee responsibility for monitoring workplace conduct and the implementation of communication programmes. In the wake of these complaints, the group took significant disciplinary action, even laying off one of the employees involved. Between 2017 and 2021, the US firefighter forces responded to an estimated annual average of 3,396 structure fires related with hot work, according to the most recent NFPA report. These fires caused average annual fatalities and civilian injuries of 19 and 120, respectively. The statistics regarding worker injuries and fatalities related with hot work paint an even darker picture. Faced with that reality, in 2023 CIE Automotive introduced a new procedure for controlling and regulating hot work at all group factories (CIE CO PR P 16) which is expected to become fully operational over the course of 2024. Under this procedure all internal or external work requiring the use of fire or combustion will be verified. ### **Fire safety self-inspections** Beyond the emergency measures in place across the factories, the group is planning to introduce a systematic method for performing regular fire safety inspections. Specifically, inspections will take place at least monthly at all group factories covered by the new hot work procedure - CIE CO PR P 16 - verifying their critical facilities and establishing action plans to address all deviations detected. The so-called Business Activity Coordination unit is therefore one of the most important areas of the health and safety effort. The vast volumes of documents and large number of companies and workers involved mean that this unit needs to be digitalised to perform its coordination work more effectively. The resulting coordination software platform is intended to reduce workplace risks, ensure compliance with applicable regulations and increase cooperation between contracting and subcontractor firms, as well as reduce the costs associated with workplace accidents. The idea is to integrate internal and external health and safety management and, if correctly applied, guarantee compliance with applicable legal requirements. To the right of the words is a large number 23 with a quotation mark above the 2. {119}------------------------------------------------ # Renewal of ISO 20400 Sustainable procurement certification In 2023, CIE Automotive renewed its ISO 20400 Sustainable procurement certification, remaining the only company in Spain to boast this quality seal. Annual renewal took place following a rigorous audit by AAERCE, the Spanish association of procurement professionals, under the sustainable procurement requirements governed by IFPSM (International Federation of Purchasing and Supply Management). The audit confirmed that the company had met the requirements formulated the previous year. With this renewal, CIE Automotive ratified the operational excellence of its Procurement Department and the contribution being made by the latter to the company's broader sustainability and social responsibility policies. To achieve this certification, which is based on UNE-15896 Value added purchasing management, the following parameters were appraised: - Purchasing policy. - Selection and monitoring of suppliers. - Purchasing processes, ESG requirements in all group purchases. - Buyer training. - Risk management, purchase specifications and internal organisation. - Alignment with new regulations and requirements in the areas of due diligence, taxonomy and diversity and inclusion. Beyond the recognition that comes with the certification, it represents a challenge for the procurement teams as it not only requires compliance with ISO 20400 by the company but also with ESG standards by its suppliers. So, for example, the company cannot make an acquisition without a positive assessment of the target's management. In this way, ISO 20400 certification reinforces the company's sustainability policies by extending them to the entire supply chain and lays the groundwork for making further progress in ESG as it requires: - Ensuring supply chain security. - Avoiding financial, environmental and reputational risks. - Inspiring confidence among investors, consumers and other stakeholders. - Fostering employee wellbeing and contributing to opening new markets for products and services. - Being prepared to achieve the decarbonisation targets CIE Automotive has set for itself, its supply chain constituting its main source of emissions (Scope 3). ## **CIE Automotive is the only Spanish** automotive parts maker to boast **ISO 20400 certification** Chairman and CEO's [statement](#page-2-0) **2023 [highlights](#page-5-0) 1** | 2 | Ready for change | |---|------------------| |---|------------------| **Record [earnings](#page-53-0) 3** **Common responsibility, [shared benefits](#page-64-0) 4** | 5 | Our response to the environmental challenge | |---|---------------------------------------------| |---|---------------------------------------------| About [this report](#page-229-0) **Responsible [management](#page-183-0) 6** [Data tables](#page-261-0) Image /page/119/Picture/30 description: The image shows the CIE Automotive logo. The number "23" has a dashed line running through the middle of it. {122}------------------------------------------------ ## ESG Supplier Portal In the automotive components sector CIE Automotive set itself apart in 2018 when it created, in a sector first, a Suppliers Portal devoted exclusively to managing ESG aspects in the supply chain. Five years on, this Portal remains a crucial tool for implementing uniform ESG requirements regardless of the nationality of the company's suppliers or their place of business. The Portal is an online platform that is free to use and accessible from the Supply Chain tab on the corporate website. Existing and prospective suppliers of products and services to CIE Automotive can register. By year-end 2023, a total of 8,000 suppliers populated the company's supplier base. Any candidates that did not complete or pass the assessment received a message encouraging them to complete the process and/or improve their scores with the help of CIE Automotive. For the first time in 2023, non-productive, or indirect suppliers, with annual procurement volume of over €500,000 are now required to register with the Portal and submit to an ESG assessment, an obligation previously limited to suppliers of productive materials, or direct suppliers. #### A **productive or direct purchase** is the purchase of products or services that form part of the final products received by the group's customers. The raw materials used in any of its technologies, the parts included in its end products (rubber, textiles, fasteners) and even subcontracting processes (heat treatments, machining) therefore fall into this category. Exceptionally, the tooling used in productive processes is also included within productive purchasing. In short, productive purchases account for over 70% of the group's total procurement spend and are the biggest source of Scope 3 emissions for CIE Automotive. In contrast a **non-productive or indirect purchase** is one that facilitates the production process but is not an integral part of the end products delivered to its customers. #### *[Refer to the Procurement families]* ### **Enhanced management** In addition to facilitating assessment, the Suppliers Portal is a source of reference and valuable information for our procurement managers. Following its redesign in 2022, a new interface was developed in 2023 to visualise, manage and extract information related with the audits conducted by CIE Automotive on current or prospective suppliers. This new feature enhances the procurement teams' management efforts and adds exclusive ESG audits to the range of traditional audits. The company's traditional audits also include a pass/fail ESG section. In 2023, it updated its Global Supply Chain Manual and General Purchasing Terms and Conditions to include its customers' chief demands. Together these two documents guide the company's suppliers. #### **Global Supply Chain Manual** This manual is a true reflection of the supply chain system and procedures. It details graphically and in plain language the Mission, Purchasing Policy, the various product and service purchasing categories, the purchasing flowchart and the associated internal procedures and the ESG requirements suppliers must meet in order to work with CIE Automotive. New commitments were added in 2023, specifically addressing: - Due diligence - Emissions reduction requirements - Decarbonisation targets #### **General Purchasing Terms and Conditions | Supplier ESG Document** The company's General Purchasing Terms and Conditions require group suppliers to endorse the company's ESG commitments if they want to work with CIE Automotive, no matter where in the world they are located. New conditions were added in 2023, specifically: - - • Modern slavery: CIE Automotive wants to ensure that there is no place for modern slavery in its supply chain, in other words, that no person is forced to work in subhuman conditions they cannot refuse on account of coercion, threats or the abuse of power. • Use of private of public security forces: Suppliers may not hire or use private or public security forces to protect the company if, due to a lack of training or control by the supplier, their deployment could give rise to human rights violations. In 2023, 100% of the suppliers CIE Automotive works with who are registered in the Suppliers Portal reported to either not using mineral conflicts or, if used in their productive processes, to being able to guarantee that they were not sourced from conflict regions. ### *Alignment with the due diligence directive* Aligned with the EU's new corporate sustainability due diligence directive and following the recommendations issued by the OECD, CIE Automotive has begun to learn about and develop a due diligence process in order to identify, prevent and manage the impact the company's operations could have on human rights and the environment along the supply chain, including its suppliers in a specific protocol. To that end it has included a specific section within the Ethics Framework section of its Global Supply Chain Manual urging its suppliers to participate in this process, introducing a due diligence report and five guidelines for correct compliance: establishing robust business management systems; identifying suppliers that supply mineral conflicts; designing a strategy for mitigating the risks detected; carrying out an external audit; and reporting on due diligence efforts in the group's annual reports. The due diligence response is currently in the process of being implemented, as follows: **1. Developing a control list** for identifying internal and external human rights and environmental risks. **2. Prioritising risks** as a function of their severity, probability and urgency. **3. Defining mitigating actions** as a function of the results of the monitoring effort. **4. Documenting the process**, defining the internal and external risks and providing training across the affected areas of the firm and to third parties. **5. Integrating human rights and environmental risks** into the overall supply chain risk map with a view to subsequently controlling them. The company will prioritise development of its response to this directive in 2024. ## **Due diligence will be a cornerstone of supplier** management in 2024 Chairman and CEO's [statement](#page-2-0) **2023 [highlights](#page-5-0)** **Ready [for change](#page-15-0)** **Record [earnings](#page-53-0)** **Common responsibility, [shared benefits](#page-64-0)** **Our response to [the environmental](#page-141-0)** **challenge** **Responsible [management](#page-183-0)** About [this report](#page-229-0) [Data tables](#page-261-0) **1** **2** **3** **4** **5** **6** Image /page/126/Picture/21 description: The image shows the logo for CIE Automotive. ESG aspects are playing an increasingly important role in that process. ### **Supplier audits** CIE Automotive assesses its suppliers' financial health in order to ensure their ability to deliver throughout the duration of its projects. Supplier evaluations take the form of process audits that assess and score them on several parameters, including planning, reception, training and skills, process, maintenance, inspection, packaging, storage, continuous improvement and environmental performance, customer satisfaction, documentation and ESG criteria. The results of the audits may be shared with the supplier. On other occasions it is the supplier that conducts a self-assessment which is then corroborated by qualified CIE Automotive professionals. Thanks to this system of self-assessment and onsite audits, in 2023 the company conducted 698\* audits, compared to 582 in 2022, an increase of 20%. In 2024, the group has set itself the target of increasing that figure by 10%, stepping up the number of onsite audits in particular. ### *External verification of ESG health using artificial intelligence* Between self-assessments and onsite audits, **in 2023 the company conducted 698 audits, growth of 20% from 2022** In 2023, CIE Automotive reached an agreement with the one of world's most important ESG ratings companies for the verification of supplier ESG compliance covering over 50% of its global procurement spend. The scope of this exercise, which began in 2022 when it was associated exclusively with governance considerations, has been widened to include: • The Red Flags Grid (fines, human rights, environment, business l predictive - conduct, corporate governance) - Country risk - Default risk - ESG scoring: analytic and predictive - Scope1 & 2 emissions The information provided by this rating company, which uses artificial intelligence and internal and external databases to check the suppliers' information, allows the group to contrast and complement the information it obtains from its Suppliers Portal. By way of conclusion, just 3 of all the suppliers evaluated presented risks in any of the above-listed areas; an action plan has been established to monitor their progress and the company is searching for alternative for these suppliers in the event the risks cannot be addressed. *(\*) One of them was carried out in the business of discontinued German forging companies.* Chairman and CEO's [statement](#page-2-0) **2023 [highlights](#page-5-0)** **Ready [for change](#page-15-0)** **Record [earnings](#page-53-0)** **Common responsibility, [shared benefits](#page-64-0)** **Our response to [the environmental](#page-141-0) challenge Responsible [management](#page-183-0)** About [this report](#page-229-0) [Data tables](#page-261-0) **1** **2** **3** **4** **5** **6** Image /page/132/Picture/25 description: The image shows the CIE Automotive logo. The company earned the foundation's three-star seal, the highest category, certifying its transparency around 90% of the 12 indicators used to analyse different practices in the area of responsible taxation. In 2023, 95% of CIE Automotive's factories were ISO 14001-certified. CIE Automotive's environmental challenge extends beyond its perimeter. It collaborates with its suppliers to reduce their emissions, purchases and generates renewable energy and cooperates with its customers to develop and manufacture parts targeted at electric vehicles, so helping to decarbonise transport. Framed by its commitment to making low-emission vehicles, CIE Automotive is developing new parts and subassembly solutions to support the OEMs with this process. As a result of its sustainability strategy and R&D initiatives, the company is already supplying specific products for the manufacture and assembly of zero- or lowemission vehicles. In collaboration with its customers it is taking a life cycle approach, building in end of life and parts reparability criteria into its designs. In addition, CIE Automotive is working on a number of R&D projects together with other companies in its value chain with a view to reducing its environmental footprint. For example, it is redesigning forged items to reduce their use of energy and extend the useful life of the machining tools. It is also redefining its packaging specifications so as to be able to use returnable cardboard boxes and introducing biomaterials and recycled plastic. #### **Membership of associations that champion climate neutrality** On the institutional front, from the Management Board of Sernauto (Spain's automotive suppliers association), CIE Automotive is encouraging climate neutrality initiatives and is collaborating to set more ambitious targets in the sector. The reasons for not continuing downstream to the end of the products' useful life are multiple and are related with the supply and supplier structure in the automotive sector: - In most of our sales agreements with customers, it is the customer who is tasked with collecting the product at the CIE Automotive factory in question, using its own logistics flows, over which CIE Automotive has neither control, responsibility or information. - The OEMs work around platforms. In other words, a given part is used in different models, with different characteristics and, therefore, different emissions. In addition, a given part of the propulsion or transmission system is used in different models, making it impossible to determine its performance in use. - Lastly, the vehicles assembled by the OEMs are, often, supplied to different countries and markets with totally different end-of-life regulations and strategies. CIE Automotive has no control over that distribution and therefore is not able to calculate the footprint associated with this step in its products' life cycle. CIE Automotive's customers ask it for environmental footprint data up to the company's gates and include those figures in their full measurements with the rest of the downstream phases without any double counting. The company uses the ReCIPE life cycle impact methodology to calculate its environmental footprint, to which end it is receiving assistance from the Basque regional government's environmental management company, IHOBE. Within the universe of activities of each company, based on the assessment that their impact is smaller, the following aspects were excluded from the analysis: #### **Upstream** - Consumption at central/sales offices outside of manufacturing facilities. - Capital goods (vehicles, machinery, tools, etc.). - Displacement of employees to go to work. - Business travel. - Upstream assets leased. - Trips to the organisation by visitors or customers. #### **Downstream** - Transport and distribution. - Processing of products sold. - Use of products sold. - End-of-life treatment of products sold. - Assets leased in subsequent phases. - Franchises. - Investments. ## To calculate the environmental footprint, **the company uses the ReCIPE methodology and has the collaboration of IHOBE** The downstream exclusions are not really exclusions as they are not included in CIE Automotive's footprint scope (from cradle to gate) for the reasons itemised earlier and in order to prevent double counting by the customer, who is the party with the information and responsibility for the downstream phases of our production. The company currently uses widely acknowledged databases such as Ecoinvent. For its electricity emissions factors, it uses updated databases in each country where it consumes electricity. One of the goals of the Supply Chain Race 2 Zero project is to compile real information about each significant product or service directly from our suppliers. However, the large majority of our suppliers are not yet prepared to provide robust, real data that they can regularly update. Note that a one-off figure is not sufficient; supplier emissions information needs to be updated as they advance on their decarbonisation and emissions-abatement plans. This is part of the coaching and mentoring work we are doing under the umbrella of this supplier programme. In 2023 surveys were undertaken in at least two factories per region in order to assess the volume of emissions associated with employee commutes to work.
